characters: DOING IT ALL WEEK, SHE CAN DO IT NOW
FINISH THE JOB, YOU GET PAID
AND TURN THAT FUCKING MUSIC OFF
YOU HAVE NOTHING BETTER TO DO
AND WHERE THE FUCK AM I
BEHIND THE COUNTER OF A SMALL-TOWN DINER.
BUSINESS, LIVING A PERFECTLY BORING LIFE
BETTY, I NEED TO TALK TO YOU...IN PERSON
IF THIS IS ABOUT DEL, FORGET IT
DIFFERENCE, YOU'RE MORE FUCKED UP THAN I
DAVID, AND IF YOU REALLY DON'T KNOW THE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tense surgery in progress. Meters flicker, instruments flash in the bright overhead light. In the midst of it al stands DR. DAVID RAVELL, 35. The master of his domain. Ravell leans forward so a NURSE can mop the sweat from hi brow as he completes a last, delicate procedure. His co workers sigh collectively with relief.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to Asst. Surgeon) Close her up, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Ravell comes out of surgery, clearly exhausted. Witho his surgical mask he is ruggedly handsome. TWO NURSES follow, attending him like a fighter fresh from the ring: CHLOE, 25, Raven-haired and striking, and JASMINE, 24, an exotic mix of African-American and Asian. BLAKE DANIELS, 58, the silver-haired Chief Surgeon, rushe the corridor. On his heels is DR. LONNIE WALSH, 33. Lonni is also conspicuously handsome, but he'll always be secon David. In everything. The look on Blake's face stops David in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: There's been a train crash near Santa Barbara. They're flying an aortal trauma here now. How can I ask you this,  David... David rubs his eyes. Thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I can do it, Blake. His bravery isn't lost on the two nurses, although Chloe exchanges a quick, covert glance with Lonnie.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Is he crazy, Jasmine? He's been on his feet for fourteen hours.

dialogues.speaker: JASMINE
dialogues.text: Chloe, it's been this way since Leslie died. Losing himself in his work, poor thing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you something to lose yourself in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quaint, Midwestern eatery. Knick-knacks and photos abound The booths and counter are packed with LOCALS. A family dining section off in one corner. TWO GUYS sitting at the counter in team jackets. The olde of the two holds up his empty coffee cup. But his WAITRES standing a couple seats down from him, doesn't move. She' completely absorbed in watching the soap opera that plays two battered, fuzzy TV sets. BETTY SIZEMORE, 30, has a wholesome attractiveness that competes with a bit too much makeup and a cheesy white waitress uniform. TWO OTHER WAITRESSES attend to customer behind her. The younger of the two guys is involved in the soap opera But the older one, still wants coffee. He gestures toward Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss? Betty leans forward, grabs the coffee pot and moves in fr of him. Without taking her eyes from the TV, she pours th java, which somehow lands in his cup without spilling a d

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: (cont'd) very impressive. That is very... (turning to others) Did anybody see that? The LOCAL GUYS around him don't even bother to look up. O course, they've seen it before. Betty smiles. 3.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: (cont'd) Thank you. Could I bother you for a little more...? Before he can even finish, Betty is topping him off with milk.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Skim, right? (tears open an Equal) And half a pack, if I remember correct... The older gentleman's mouth works a bit but nothing comes out. He is flabbergasted by her attention to detail. She looks at the younger man, who is still following the show gobbling down a huge bacon burger. BETTY (cont'd) You know, you're never too young to start on a lean meat substitute... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna try some turkey bacon on that?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGER MAN
dialogues.text: You want a tip when I'm through?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: It's your body... Betty turns back to change pots. The older man watches he intently as the younger of the two mumbles to himself.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGER MAN
dialogues.text: (to himself) That's right, so why don't you get up off it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wesley... (to Betty) I've told him the same thing. Thanks for the suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: No problem. Betty flashes the men a winning smile and moves off, one always on the TV as she approaches two local types. SHERIFF ELDEN BALLARD, 32, a short, tightly wound little sitting at his own booth. Ballard is spit and polish all way: creases in his shirt, a glossy shine on his shoes. Badge proudly displayed. He sits with ROY OSTREY, 31, a gangly, bookish local reporter. Betty drops five ketchup packets and four mayonnaise packets on table for him. Another smile.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Hi, Betty. You're looking good...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Roy, you're sweet... a big liar, but sweet. I liked your editorial this morning...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Oh, appreciate it. I was trying to, ahh, give a sense of history to...

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Yeah, it was great. Really put the whole idea of "church bake sales" in perspective...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You know, Elden, some people actually read more than just the Classifieds...

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Why don't you go back to doing something you're good at... like that Lonelyhearts column? (chuckles to himself) I'll take a refill there, Betty... His cup is full before he can even finish the sentence.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Hey, Sheriff. How's everything?

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Oh, you know, the usual... keeping the world safe.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I meant your food.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Oh, right... 's fine. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I thought you said the eggs weren't...

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: It's fine. Mind your own meal...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You should get the order you want.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: And you should keep your nose out of another man's omelette... (to Betty) It's no big deal, Betty.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: There's yolks in there, huh? It's no prob'... gotta keep you on track. Betty grabs Ballard's plate without another word, gives h reassuring rub on the shoulders and moves off. He smiles appreciatively after her, then turns on Roy.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Why you always gotta embarrass me? I been eating lunch with you since grade school and you always gotta embarrass me!

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: They're just eggs, Elden, how embarrassing can eggs be?

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: plenty

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Who eats eggs for lunch, anyhow?

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Mind your own business. You just said that shit so you could look at her a little longer, anyway... Still carrying Ballard's plate, she returns to the count

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Come on, guys, I told you it's egg whites only for the Sheriff... (quietly) I put him in that 'zone' thing.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: Well, it better be a pretty good size zone if he's in it... Betty and the cooks share a quick laugh. They move to cha his order while Betty glances up at the TV. 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnie catches up to Blake in the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: LONNIE
dialogues.text: Blake, I can handle that transplant!

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: We need someone with the right kind of experience, Lonnie.

dialogues.speaker: LONNIE
dialogues.text: Even if he's falling asleep on his feet?

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Lonnie, it's a complex procedure. Why don't you observe?

dialogues.speaker: LONNIE
dialogues.text: I'm not some snot-nosed resident fresh out of medical school, Blake.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: No, you're not. You're a good doctor, Lonnie, but you're not David Ravell. I've made my decision. Now, if you'll excuse me Blake exits. The camera moves in to hold on a CLOSEUP of Lonnie's face as he simmers in anger. Music soars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plates of food are piling up on the shelf in front of the  COOKS. One of them turns the TV off by remote.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Hey! We were watching that!

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: The other girls've got orders up... we're not one 'a them goddamn Nelson families, y'know. Betty snatches up several plates to help out. Ballard's f appears with A CLATTER of porcelain.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: It's "Nielson"...

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, we ain't one ‘a them, neither. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on now...

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: When you gonna get those things fixed, anyhow?

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: When you all quit watching ‘em for a living... Frustrated, Betty delivers several plates and drops them tables where the people know her by name. She moves off toward FOUR LOCAL GUYS in a booth jangling their empty cu Betty weaves her way over to them and pours refills. When hand strays around to touch her ass, she pushes it away w her foot and keeps right on pouring. Absently, Betty take look around the restaurant. The other waitresses are gone and no one is behind the grill. Alarmed, she pushes throu the double doors into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE WAITRESSES, along with the DISHWASHER and TWO COOKS standing in a row waiting for her.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: alright, I get it, no more TV. Sorry. No one moves, then DARLENE leads them in a huge SURPRISE! They produce a life-size cardboard cut-out of Dr. David Ravell, who looks dashing in his green hospital scrubs.  Betty backs up in disbelief. BETTY (cont'd) Oh my gosh, this is so embarrassing! Where did you ever find this?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: On the goddamn internet, where else?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: You're joking...

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: nope, got him at "T.V. Hunks with Sweet Little Asses.Com."

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Seventy-five dollars...

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: Seventy-eight fifty. (everyone looks at him) Well, I paid for the damn thing, I oughta know.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: C'mon, Betty! Pose with him! Betty laughs and puts her arm around the cardboard man. A flash photo is taken. A cupcake with a single candle is placed in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: One candle... uh-oh, you're getting up there! Doesn't David like 'em young?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I'm over the hill, what can I say? Darlene gives Betty an envelope with cash showing.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: A little something for those nursing classes you've been wanting to take...

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: but keep putting off thanks to a certain husband we won't mention...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh, guys, you didn't have to do that!

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: So how you gonna celebrate? Del takin'  you into Wichita for a big fancy dinner? The others laugh; they know better. So does Betty.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Yeah, Dairy Queen, maybe... Oh, I should probably call him. Thanks, you guys...

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: Alright, alright, come on... I'm not running no bed & breakfast, we got customers. Let's go... Smiling, Betty grabs a wall phone as the others mingle ab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trailer/office of a small-time car dealership. As the PHONE RINGS, the CAMERA PANS across pictures of DEL SIZEM 35, dressed as Napoleon, Caesar and Abe Lincoln, arms rai in a high-energy sales pitch. The PHONE RINGS again. We see a framed certificate of achievement from General Motors, dated 1986. After the THIRD RING an ANSWERING MACHINE clicks on. It's loud.

dialogues.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE
dialogues.text: (Del's voice) Hello there! You've reached Sizemore Motors, home of the best selection of used General Motors cars in the Big Springs - Fair Oaks area. We can't come to the phone right now 'cause we're out making a sale, so leave us a message; better yet, come on down and steal one 'a these beauties right out from under us! Coffee's always on!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hi Del, it's me. I guess you're busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del's very busy. He's on the rented sofa in the trailer's lounge, screwing his secretary, JOYCE. But as he rocks th couch, he's listening to Betty's message.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I know you want the Oldsmobile back tonight, so... I was wondering if I could take one of the new Buicks. Del pulls out and lurches across the room. He reaches for the desk phone but misses, spilling down onto the carpet. gathers himself and his pants up in disgust, pawing aroun the desktop until he finds the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, call me when you--

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, whoa! Hang on a second there, baby. Why do you need one of the new Buicks?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Oh, you're there. You sound out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I ran back in to get the phone. 10. The answering machine is on, so their VOICES are BOOMING. phone cord is stretched across the trailer as he tries to back to Joyce. He motions for her to join him but she remains where she is, fuming.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I don't need one, but it's kind of a special night, and--

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What's so special about it? LONG PAUSE. Joyce looks at Del, incredulous. Then pissed He signals to hold on.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Sue Ann's taking me out and I thought it might be fun to go in a nice car... Joyce wriggles to a sitting position and begins to pull u her panties. Del shoots her a look that says 'I'm not finished yet!' They pantomime frantically back and forth until Joyce throws him the finger and SLAMS out the door.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (V.0)
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Nothing... it's, ahh, busy here. Look, you don't need a LeSabre to go out with Sue Ann. Take the blue Corsica. I'll see you when I get home. He throws the phone onto the cradle, then bangs on a wind to get Joyce's attention as she fires up a smoke.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (through the pane) Shit! Joyce, open the damn gate, will you?! As Del zips up his pants Joyce trudges across the lot to bring in the "Closed For Lunch" sign and open the gate. D silently studies the much nicer car lot next door for a moment. He takes in the banners, the signs, etc. DEL (cont'd) that's what we need, some goddamn flags. 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty enters the office. Joyce is on the phone. She looks up, irritated, and says something under her breath to the caller.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Uhh, no, we haven't picked a date yet... well, once he dumps her we will. (to Betty) He's out pricing banners... I don't expect him back.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: "Banners?"

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: You know, flags and shit... he said "for a livelier look" or something. Betty nods and swaps her car keys for a set Joyce gives h JOYCE (cont'd) "S too bad about the LeSabres... they're a really sweet ride. As Joyce prattles on, Betty notices the Buick LeSabre key a rack behind her. She sidles around Joyce, deftly remove set from the hook and drops them in her purse. She smiles and starts to wave goodbye as Joyce puts her call on hold  10 JOYCE (cont'd) Need something else?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: No, I was just... How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Great. Good. Content...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh. How come?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I dunno. Job satisfaction, I guess... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's things at the Tip Top?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: They're fine... you miss it?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: You must be joking. 12.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Hmm. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Del get that car he sold you up and running yet?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, he's got things up and running, alright...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: ‘Kay, good. Bye, then...

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. (back to phone) Anyway, I'm thinking Easter, 'cause I just fucking love pastels. She whispers, then laughs loudly as Betty leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cardboard doctor is standing next to Betty's Olds. Sh thinks about leaving him, but picks him up and tosses him into a blue Corsica. He lands with his face against the passenger window.  11 12 13 14 She stands for a moment by the Corsica, dangling the LeSa keys before her eyes. Suddenly, she jumps inside the Chevrolet and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blue Corsica leaves the parking lot and pulls onto th street. The car makes an abrupt turn into a trailer park directly behind the car lot and glides to a halt behind a of battered airstreams. Betty gets outs of the Chevy and looks back: the handsome face of Doctor David Ravell is staring at her from the ca

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ, what am I gonna do with you? She goes back to pick him up, then starts off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A row of cheap trailers on both sides of a crumbling driveway. Betty appears with her cardboard man tucked und one arm and then disappears behind a pickup truck. 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tosses the cardboard "David" over a concrete slab wal climbs over herself and walks straight to the LeSabres. H key opens the last one - maroon. She puts the doctor on t passenger seat, gets in the car and inhales the new car smell. Joyce can be seen inside the trailer, still talking on th phone. She misses the whole scene as she works on her nai

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: We deserve this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty has the car at 75 m.p.h., on the rural Kansas roads wheat fields for miles on both sides of her. The RADIO is blasting Bonnie Raitt and she's singing along. She sees her speed and punches the accelerator ... 80 m.p  15 16 85 ... 90 m.p.h. She turns the radio up louder. When she approaches a sign saying "You are leaving Kansas Betty suddenly becomes self-conscious. She eases up on th gas ... slows down ... does a U-turn and heads back towar Fair Oaks. She glances wistfully in her rear view mirror the billboard that quickly fades into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty enters a modest residential neighborhood and pulls a driveway. She parks in a detached garage and looks over the cardboard David. There's no way he's going in the hou She puts him in the trunk and closes the garage door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks several houses down. On her way to the door we hear a DOG BARKING, CHILDREN and GENERAL COMMOTION from inside. SUE ANN ROGERS answers Betty's knock. Her hair is matted with sweat as she struggles with CHILDREN, ages 4, and 6 months. Suddenly, Sue Ann is hit by an errant rubbe ball.

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: Hey, darling... oww! Sorry, got my own little Gulf War going on here. Betty takes the baby as Sue Ann pulls a videotape from a shelf. It's all one move; they do this every day. 14.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Did you watch it yet?

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: Sure did. I'll tell you, if that man was any better looking it'd be a crime 'a some sort...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Yep. Hey, I got a surprise for tonight. We're going to the Starlite in style!

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: Oh, Betty--

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I'll give you a hint. If you scrunch up your eyes a bit it looks just like a Jaguar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I'm really sorry, I was gonna call you about tonight. Larry's got a lodge meeting. There's no way I can get a sitter this fast.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (disappointed) No... what about your sister?

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: I can't ask her again-- Nathan, stop it! Jesse, don't take that, hit back!-- I feel terrible, hon. After a beat

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: You sure? Maybe next week we could...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. No, we'll do it later. 'S only a birthday, right? I'll have another one next year... Betty forces a smile, kisses the baby and hands it back t Sue Ann, who hands her the videotape.

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: Aahbh... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what color is it? 15.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: The LeSabre!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Maroon. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stole it.

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: He wasn't going to let us use it, so I just took it.  17

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: Oh, I wish we could just get in it and drive, and drive, and drive!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too.

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: Sorry, hon. Happy Birthday...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I gotta go make dinner. Betty throws her a look as Sue Ann closes the door. Betty turns around, frustrated. She starts yanking her apron of as she crosses the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A low-end ranch. A worn-out sofa and loveseat form an 'L' that dominates the living room. Romance novels line a sma bookcase. SIX CANARIES in cages chatter away in the kitch Del sits at the dining room table, agitated. He is presen attacking a pork chop, baked beans and a loaf of Wonderbr All we hear is A FORK CLICKING and BIRDS CHIRPING. Betty stands at the breakfast counter, barefoot, still in her uniform and quietly eating a salad.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Sure you don't want any salad?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: No, I do not want any goddamn... what was all that shit on the phone about the new Buicks? 16.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I told you. Sue Ann was gonna take me out tonight, but...

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: She's not comfortable in a Corsica? 'S got air and leather...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I took the blue Corsica, Del. Relax.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: All right, then. Actually, I'm glad you're going out. I got something going  on tonight. Some serious clients, with real potential. Del BELCHES, smiles, then CLUCKS at the birds nearby.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: like the water purifiers?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Or the vitamins? Or the...? Del almost comes out of his chair, pointing his finger at her.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Hey, the FDA screwed me on that when they changed the law, and you know it! (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, 'least I try shit, still got some dreams left... you're a goddamn waitress, what do you got?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I got you, Del...

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: well, then you ain't got much.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh, I know. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, who're these clients?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Couple 'a guys in from outta town. They want to see the new LeSabres. Betty hides her reaction. 17. DEL (cont'd) And I don't need Sue Ann's fat ass around to fuck it up...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Just knock it off, ‘kay? Anyhow, they're 97's, they're not even new.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: They're new to us... Truce for a moment. Del plucks a copy of Soap Opera Guide  18 from Betty's purse while absently taking a bite from Bett cupcake. He narrowly misses the candle. DEL (cont'd) Jesus... you know these actors are mainly models, which are mainly fags. They've done studies. The rest're assholes. But you know what bugs me most about these soaps? She silently mimics him as he says... DEL (cont'd) It's people with no lives watching other people's fake lives.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess there's nothing like watching those tenpins fall, huh, Del?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: That is a skill! Del lurches to his feet and crosses to the bird cages as canaries CHIRP and SING EXCITEDLY at his approach. DEL (cont'd) Daddy's here, babies... daddy's here. (to Betty) Be back later... clean up. He exits. She collects his dirty dishes, puts them in the sink and starts to wash them. Then she stops.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: What the hell am I doing? She drops the dishes with a clatter, pours herself a glas wine, lights the candle on her deflowered cupcake and ope the one card on the table.
a traditional greeting from her grandparents. Red hearts lace. A color photo of them enclosed. Betty smiles at this. After moment, she quietly sings a quick refrain of "Happy Birthday" to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing wrapped only in a towel, Lonnie speaks into the  19 20 phone.

dialogues.speaker: LONNIE
dialogues.text: Tell me something good, Sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beautiful nurse Chloe is curled up seductively on her sofa with her phone in one hand and a cigarette in the ot

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: We're all set. I told him my car's in the shop. He said he'd be happy to give me a ride home.

dialogues.speaker: LONNIE
dialogues.text: (v.0.) You're beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Tell me something I don't know... Betty hits FAST FORWARD. Characters flit on and off the screen at top speed until David Ravell appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chloe's magnificent legs are folded into the seat of Davi 560 SL. She struggles with her seatbelt, so he helps her. She makes sure their hands touch.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Thanks for pulling over, David... I can't go that fast without taking a breather.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sorry... it's nice to see what this little beauty can do, though. I guess, somehow, all that speed helps me forget the past... 19.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I'm sure it does... (touching the seats) Mmm, leather. How far do they recline? David smiles, a little uncomfortable. CHLOE (cont'd) Listen, David, I know I've said it  21 22 before, but I want to tell you again how sorry I am about your wife. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must make you scared to get close to someone again. She puts her hand over his on the gear shift. A moment. Finally, he has to move her fingers to start the car. CHLOE (cont'd) Let's not go... not yet. BETTY sits on an old couch in the den and watches, eyes g to the screen. Suddenly, she hears the sound of TIRES ON GRAVEL. HEADLIGHTS sweep across the window.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Damn! She hits PAUSE and crosses to look out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del gets out of a black Lincoln Town Car, followed by CHA and WESLEY - the guys in the team jackets from the diner. Charlie is 63 years old. He wears a dress shirt, slacks a docksiders. The suburban father look. Wesley is 28. He's in jeans, T-shirt and white Reeboks. C cut; the kid who used to mow your parents’ lawn. Betty quickly snaps out the light and closes the door unt it is open only a crack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del swaggers into the house. The two men follow politely.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: you can have the best damn running backs in the world, somebody's still gotta block for ‘em. 20.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You're a hundred percent right. They rely on what's-his-name's arm too much... Del stops and looks around, deflated by the mess. The den is only a short flight of steps from the living r and the kitchen. Betty has a clean view of both from whe she sits on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hears Del come in, but doesn't take her eyes off the screen.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: My apologies, gentlemen. I asked my wife to straighten this shit up before she went out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del crosses to an old stereo and puts on an LP. He smiles the music overtakes the room. Charlie and Wesley stand nearby, appreciating the quaintness of the surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Now, what can I get you gentlemen to drink? Del crosses to the cupboard. Charlie and Wesley stand leisurely in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Bourbon, little water, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Beer, please.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You got it. Wesley looks at a wedding portrait of Del and Betty.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Hey... you got a fine one right here!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wesley... (to Del) Your wife's a very lovely woman. Have I seen her before? 21.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: If you ate at the Tip Top you did.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, with the coffee...

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Yep, Betty pours a pretty mean cup. Del reaches into the fridge and produces a Miller for Wes then mixes two drinks and walks into the dining room and Charlie and Wesley follow to the table and sit down.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I like this. I like doing business in the home. It's cozy... (noticing the card and cupcake) Who's birthday?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Ahh... my wife's.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: What'd you get her?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh, umm, a car. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, to a successful transaction... They raise their glasses and drink. Del tosses back his drink in one gulp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chloe is on top of David, kissing him on the mouth as he resists. He finally has to push her away forcibly, and we hear a TEARING SOUND. Chloe's blouse has been ripped.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Chloe. She starts to cry. David reaches out to comfort her. DAVID (cont'd) It's not that I don't find you attractive. I'm just not ready... David looks up to find her lips on his. In spite of himse he gives in to the warmth of her kiss and responds hungri Betty is mesmerized. 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men have retired into the dining room, sitting or standing around a worn wooded table. Charlie and Wesley a just finishing their drinks.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: All right gentlemen, let's get down to it. I need to know if you're for real.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: If we're for real?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You don't exactly look like drug dealers.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Isn't that the point?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I don't have time to screw around. I got buyers in Dallas, Houston and Vegas who are ready to snap this stuff up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We appreciate that. But you just poured me a drink, I'd like to enjoy your hospitality for a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Fine. You got five...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It's a nice place you got here. Real comfortable. Sweet little town, Fair Oaks. You like it here?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: (laughs) Are you kidding me? What's to like?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Seems like a nice place.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: It is, if you like idiots...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: It's a small town, man. I never should have left Omaha. People here think 23. small. They act small. They're a bunch  of dumb fucks.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You better believe it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Could you give us an example?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Of what?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'm asking you for an example of one of these dumb fucks being a dumb fuck.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I don't follow...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You're not a dumb fuck, are you, Del?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: (warily) No...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I didn't think so. So, give me an example of a stupid person doing a stupid thing. Not being stupid, you're equipped to recognize it.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Are we gonna do business here, or not?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Relax, we brought the cash.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'm just curious. Can't you give me an example?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: (annoyed) All right ... lemme see ... okay, new Burger King opens up. These assholes get excited and start lining up. Like it's some five star restaurant. The place is mobbed. Right? 24.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hmmmm. "Five Stars," huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that stupid, Wesley?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: No, that's ignorant. They just don't know any better.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That's what I thought. (to Del) You better give me another example.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: This is bullshit, can we get down to business here, please? Off a look from Charlie, Wesley produces a pistol and gen nudges the barrel into Del's ear.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ!

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: He's waiting...

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Okay, uh... the, umm, Injuns're stupid.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: "Tnjuns?"

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You did not just say "Injuns," Del.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: The Indians, Injuns, whatever. They're always drunk and doing stupid things.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Driving their cars into trees... puking on the sidewalk... stupid shit!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Let's see... around here that would be Kiowa, Kickapoo or Osage, if I'm not mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I... I don't know... 25.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, my idea of stupid is very different from yours. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So here's how this is gonna work. Would you take your socks off, please?

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: My socks?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: You heard the man. Del slowly takes his shoes and socks off. He's sweating, trembling.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'm gonna talk to you and when I'm finished, you can answer. But I don't like being interrupted. Now roll them into a ball... Del does it.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, please... Please, God.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: and put them in your mouth. At a sharp look from Charlie, Del obediently stuffs the s into his mouth and starts to cry. Wesley produces a roll duct tape and fastens Del's hands to the back of his chai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is glued to the TV, oblivious to the men. Chloe and David are still talking in his car. She continues to cry.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (v.0.) You're wonderful, Chloe, you are... But I just know there's something special out there for me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Now I'm gonna tell you what stupid is. Stupid is taking something that doesn't belong to you. Right Wesley? 26.  Del nods;

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Stupid is trying to sell it to other people who are, by their very nature, untrustworthy.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: That is so right.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Stupid is calling people in Kansas City who are affiliated with the rightful owners of the thing you stole, and trying to sell it to them. Right Wesley?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Now, that's really stupid.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So you see, we have totally different ideas of what's stupid and what's not. Don't we? crying, sweating. CHARLIE (cont'd) Good. Now we're getting somewhere. You agree that you were stupid? Del nods again. Wesley collects Charlie's glass and mixes him another drink. He gets a beer for himself and stands behind Del. Charlie sips his drink slowly, savoring it. CHARLIE (cont'd) You know, a hundred and fifty years ago you'd have been scalped for that remark about Native Americans. Right here where your house is - you'd have been scalped.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Hell of a way to die.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It wasn't always fatal, Wesley. We could scalp Del right now, and he'd be plenty alive to tell us how it feels. Del's eyes get huge.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's pretty simple, too. (BEAT)

28 First you take a knife and just draw a mark right across the hairline. Wesley produces a long knife and traces a line across the very top of Del's forehead. Trickles of blood wind their down his brow. Del is MOANING and PANTING through his soc CHARLIE (cont'd) Hold still, Del, we're just talking here... (pointing to a spot) Then you grab a big handful of hair and pull as you cut. It's amazing how easily the scalp comes off.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: A mark, huh? Wesley takes a jab at Del's forehead with his knife, leav a small cut. Del starts twitching, rocking back and forth as Wesley gr a fistful of his hair. WESLEY (cont'd) Shut the fuck up! I bleed more than that when I shave... Del stops moving. He breathes furiously through his nostr

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Now. I want to know the particulars of your stupid act: how you got what doesn't belong to you, who helped you get it, and of course, where it is now. Charlie pulls the socks out of Del's mouth. Del splutters gasping for air.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: It's in the Buick! I swear to God it's all there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David enters. Blake nods to him grimly.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You wanted to see me, Blake?

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: I wish I could say I had good news. (off David's look) David, I'll get right to the point.  29 Chloe Jensen has filed charges of sexual 28. assault against you. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can continue to practice at L.A. County, but I'm afraid I have to revoke your privileges here at Loma Vista until this is resolved. HOLD on David's shocked expression ... MUSIC UP AS

dialogues.speaker: PLEASE DON'T KILL ME
dialogues.text: Betty's not sure what Del said, but the panic in his voic got through. She hits PAUSE and takes a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del is facing her, tiny rivulets of blood running into hi terrified eyes. Wesley stands at his shoulder, still hold a handful of his hair, still poised with the knife.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: I got it from a truck driver named Duane Cooley, out of Amarillo. He brings my cars down from Detroit. But I haven't touched it, I swear to you... Please! Please! Please! Annoyed, Charlie stuffs the socks back in Del's mouth. Betty stares. Her gaze shifts from Del to Wesley, drawn b Wesley's demonic expression.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Consider yourself lucky. Luckier than those 'Injuns' you have such contempt for. Wesley stares at the top of Del's head. Betty stares at Wesley. Charlie walks into the kitchen for another drink. CHARLIE (cont'd) I'll tell you, if anyone got a raw deal it's the American Indian. This country has a black mark on its soul for what was done to them. Wesley's nostrils flare. Betty leans forward. CHARLIE (cont'd) I'm all for them owning casinos, getting  30 31 rich off the white man's greed. It's a beautiful piece of irony, isn't it, Wesley? 29.

dialogues.speaker: IT SURE IS
dialogues.text: And with a long SCREAM, Wesley rips Del's scalp from his head. It makes a sickening sound like fabric tearing. For long moment, there is only silence. An eerie silence. Suddenly, Del SCREAMS into his socks and thrashes in his seat, blood pouring down his head on all sides. Somehow, he manages to get to his feet, the chair still t to him, and begins smashing into whatever is near. Blood flies and curios shatter as Del thunders through the room dying bull, only messier. It's quite a show.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS CHRIST
dialogues.text: Wesley steps back, staring at the dripping scalp in his h as if wondering how it got there. Betty is transfixed, horrified. Charlie re-enters. The two men look at each other over De MUFFLED SCREAMS as he plows headlong into wooden paneling china cabinet, and finally, back toward them near the breakfast counter. Del bashes blindly into it. CHARLIE (cont'd) (to Wesley) What the fuck is the matter with you?! Wesley is practically foaming at the mouth, still rushing what he did. Charlie draws a silenced pistol and merciful SHOOTS Del through the head. The big man stops suddenly, blinks once or twice, topples over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty points her remote at the dining room and clicks it, if trying to make the image disappear. Finally, she gives up, slowly turning away from the carnage and aims at the "A Reason to Love" pauses on the face of David Ravell and Betty sits in absolute silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 33 Charlie quickly begins to hide their tracks, producing a plastic baggie and collecting the beer cans and his own glass. He also wipes down the fridge as Wesley watches.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind? You scalped him! 30.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: You told me how to do it!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That was to get him to talk! (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get rid of that thing, will you? Wesley crosses to the garbage can, steps on the lever. He looks at the scalp one more time before dropping it in.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is great - just great! Now we don't know where the goddamn stuff is.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: He told us it's in the Buick.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We don't know which Buick, do we?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Well, why'd you shoot him?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I had to shoot him! It was the only decent thing to do. They exit the house. CHARLIE (0.S.) (cont'd) This is very unprofessional, Wesley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is still in the family room, staring at the TV. She pushes ‘play' again and David Ravell begins to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue Ann comes out of her house, balancing a homemade cake front of her. The candles give off an unearthly glow as s  34 35 36 picks her way up the Sizemore's gravel drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is catatonic, staring at the frozen image of David Ravell on her TV. Downstairs, Sue Ann comes in. 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday to you! Happy Birthday to you! Happy Birthday, dear-- A terrified SCREAM as the cake lands unceremoniously on t entryway.

dialogues.speaker: ON BETTY
dialogues.text: As she hits 'Play':

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: you're wonderful, Chloe, you are... But I just know there's something special out there for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy enters the foyer and looks around, carrying a pad and in hand. He hears VOICES from the kitchen, sees FLASHBULB going off. He sneaks down the hall when A VOICE stops him

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Hang on there, Roy. Nobody comes in.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Elden called me. He wants to, ahh, make a statement for the paper... The deputy nods him through and Roy moves off toward the sewing room where he has spotted Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is packing an overnight bag on her bed when Roy ent and quietly closes the door behind him. She is working wi a purpose, almost like a different person from the woman first met. Still bright and cheerful, but with a willful glint in her eye. Determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Betty. Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I'm great, good, content. (stopping) What happened to your arm, Roy?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing, it's fine. I just need to keep it wrapped for a few... 32.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Make sure it's elevated...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: You want me to make you a sling? It's no problem... Betty starts whipping a T-shirt into place but stops abruptly. She turns curiously to Roy. BETTY (cont'd) What're you doing here, Roy?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Well, I was worried about you and I wanted to make sure you were alright... and I guess I was sort of hoping I could ask you about what happened...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh, that... Sure, I saw the whole thing. It was disgusting!

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: My God... did you get a look at who did it?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You did? Was it anyone that you...?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: It was Chloe... Sheriff Ballard enters the house, surveys the scene of th crime where one deputy wipes blood off his boot with a pa towel, and erupts when he sees Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you guys wanna try not stepping directly in the evidence, please? (to Roy) Ostrey, you and your goddamn police scanner! I leave for ten minutes and... Betty, I'm sorry about this. He motions to a female officer. 33. BALLARD (cont'd) Why don't you take her down to the station? We'll be along in a bit... She leads Betty out the kitchen door.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: ‘Night, guys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ballard leads Roy into the next room...

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Okay, let's go... I got nothing for the record yet.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Oww! My arm, careful!

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Ahh, what'd you do now... fall off your bike again?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: No, it's nothing, I... my piranha just mauled me a little when I layed their food out.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Good God...they're meat eaters, Roy, just drop the shit in there!

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I can't...they prefer a more formal presentation. I don't usually go so close to the surface, but I was...

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: ...you are so goddamn weird. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 39 Oh, and by the way, get the hell outta here!

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: No, Elden, I need to...

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: You need to get yourself gone from my crime scene. And leave Betty alone, she's... 34.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: She knows who killed Del. Elden, she said it was a woman.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: It wasn't a woman.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Yes it was. Betty saw the whole thing! Your killer's name is Chloe...

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: I'm tellin' you it wasn't no woman, Roy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ballard drags Roy into the living room, where he sees Del He has been turned upright and is being carefully examine

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: You think a woman did that?! Roy runs into the kitchen, covering his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ballard and his cronies delight in watching Roy struggle the dry heaves. Roy runs to the kitchen sink, almost lose it, then wipes his mouth with a paper towel.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Kinda’ looks like a burnt out roman candle, don't he? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del must've sold a lemon to the wrong Indian, and got paid back the old  fashioned way. Them Kickapoos get pretty mean when they drink... Roy sees Del's scalp in the garbage can as he goes to dro his crumpled towel inside.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: So, you think you're gonna find his scalp hanging in some tepee?

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: They no longer live in tepees, Mr. College Graduate. 35.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Did you send anyone out there?

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: You bet I did. I got a squad car on the way to the reservation right now.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Bad idea

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: You just go write your little story, Roy. I'll handle the police work...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You better handle what's in this garbage can first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every car on the lot has its trunk open and spare tire on ground behind it. Charlie and Wesley are at the last car.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I still don't understand how you knew Del was telling the truth.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I saw his soul Wesley. He was face to face with his God, and no one lies in that situation. But your Geronimo act rattled me, and I abandoned my instincts. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never abandon you instincts.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I didn't. You gave me a look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What 'look'?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: That one look you got! I thought you were done, so I took him out...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I wasn't done, I was just sick of hearing him whine. And you didn't take him out, you scalped him. Christ, I almost puked, did I tell you that?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Well, why'd you have to tell that Indian story? 36.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What the hell does that mean? If I'd told a Ty Cobb story would you have clubbed him to death with a bat? Wesley is stung. Charlie slams the last trunk in disgust. The rest remain where they are; open. CHARLIE (cont'd) It's not here. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: You just gonna leave these cars sitting here like this?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why not, it'll confuse ‘em... gotta do something, now that you fucked it up.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I wanted to make a statement.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something. In our business you can't put food on the table if your phone doesn't ring. The guys who get the calls are good - not flashy, just good. They get in, they get out. Nobody knows a goddamn thing. Understand? Boom, boom, boom. Three in the head and you know they're dead.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: that's a good motto.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Fine, I'll get you a bumpersticker, but  41 you better start believing it! It's the only statement you need to make. INT. POLICE STATION / OBSERVATION ROOM - NIGHT Al Betty is questioned in a holding room by a POLICE OFFICER a DOCTOR. Ballard and Roy watch through a window.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: And did your husband know these people?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Sort of...but he ignored them.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: And how did that make you feel, Betty? 37.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I felt all cold inside. And angry. Ballard looks both ways to make sure he won't be overhear

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: I questioned Joyce about all this...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Seems she was pretty familiar with 'ol Del. On a regular basis, if you get my drift...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: and half the other guys in this town. Including you, I believe...

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Junior year!

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Anyway, so what?

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: So? ... Suppose Betty found out about them?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You said a woman couldn't have done it.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: A woman can write a check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're saying Betty Sizemore - our Betty Sizemore--who you were in swing choir with--has now hired somebody to scalp her husband in her own kitchen while she watched? You're amazing.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: 'S just a theory...just 'cause I'm thinking it don't mean I like it. The doctor comes out of the holding room. BALLARD (cont'd) How is she? 38.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: She's in a kind of shock. I see all the signs of a post-traumatic reaction with possible dissociative symptoms.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Could I have that in American?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: It's a type of altered state...it allows a traumatized person to continue functioning.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: So she did witness it?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Oh, you're sharp as a tack, Elden.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: That's it! YOU'RE GONE! He spins Roy around and marches him toward the door, one bent behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Oww, the arm, the arm!

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: You just don't know when to quit, Roy! You were jealous of me when I got hall monitor in seventh grade, and you're still jealous now!!!

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: One question, Doctor, please! (outside the door) You can't do this! I'm the  42 43 press, I have rights!!

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: That's right, you have the right to remain silent. Ballard pushes Roy out the door. As he returns, Roy reapp behind him, leaning in to listen. Ballard doesn't see him BALLARD (cont'd) Sorry you had to see that. You were saying?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I was saying that it seems probable that she witnessed the murder, but her memory of it is gone, at least for the time being. I also think you ought to have her 39. stay with someone tonight. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any idea who Chloe or Lonnie are?

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: No... Friends from the diner maybe?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Well, you should find out. She keeps talking about them... Ballard nods, sure he's got a clue here. He looks in at B again, just as she begins repacking her travel bag. He frowns at this, his suspicions fueled all the more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police car pulls up to Sue Ann's house. Betty gets out, carrying her overnight bag. Sue Ann appears, embraces her and leads her inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty lies down in a bright red race car bed. Sue Ann tuc her in and turns out the light.

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: Let me know if you need anything, okay?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Are you and Larry happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I dunno... enough, I s'pose.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Then you should treasure that... you gotta hold on to whatever you got that's any good, even if it's only a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: All you been through... I ever tell you what a good friend you are?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: All the time...

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: Well, you are. After a beat... 40.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Something bad happened to Del and me, didn't it?

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: Yeah, hon. Real bad. You just get some sleep, everything's gonna be fine.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Sue Ann, I'm sorry about all this, but I just know there's something special out there for me... Sue Ann looks down at her friend, troubled. She strokes Betty's hair gently and kisses her. After she leaves, Bet lies awake, staring at the ceiling. A mobile dangles overhead.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The Mickey Mouse clock on the wall reads 3:30. Beneath it Betty is sitting up in bed, wide awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty comes down the stairs without a sound. She finds a and paper near the phone and writes a note. INSERT: Dear Del: This is the hardest thing I've ever done and I can't  even face you. But I need to be honest. We haven't been happy for a long time. You always say people have some. 45 46 47 48 49 need their space, and now you'll I'm sorry. Betty She takes off her wedding band and puts it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty raises the garage door, tosses her overnight bag an birthday money envelope into the LeSabre, and gets in. She drives through Fair Oaks, past the town limits. She keeps on driving until her car recedes into the moonlit prairie horizon. 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes to a sudden halt in front of the "You are Leavi Kansas" billboard. She stares hard at it through the windshield. Suddenly, she hits the gas and bolts off alon the Oklahoma blacktop. She never looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty yawns, looks at her watch and increases her speed. When she sees a sign for a MOTEL ahead, she pulls off the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She parks at a truck stop/restaurant/motel complex, hops and runs to the motel office window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty enters her room, immediately turns on the TV, and p down on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: 50 51 And now we return to "A Reason to Love."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowded truck stop in the Texas flatlands. THREE TRUCK DRIVERS in jeans, flannel shirts and denim jackets walk across the parking lot. One is an old, grizzled veteran with a salt-and-pepper stubble and a greasy CAT cap on his head. It's CHARLIE. Next to him is DUANE, a burly young driver in fancy cowbo boots. Flanking Duane is WESLEY.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: So you got Asian women?

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: (Southern accent) Sure, I got Asian. Got black, white, any color you like, video and magazine. Got fat chicks and animals too, if you want ‘em. They're extra...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Mmmm. Well, it was a piece of luck running into you, Duane. I thought I was 42. gonna have to take Wesley out and hose him down. All he talks about is those Japanese gals.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I like ‘em small. When you're inside a little Asian chick, it's like your dick is the axle that holds her body together.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: That's nicely put. You outta get yourself to Thailand... They reach Duane's truck, an empty car-carrier with Michi plates, and climb up into the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Confederate flags criss-cross over Duane's CB unit. O the dashboard is a Rebel flag pin, a bumper sticker that "The South Will Rise Again" and a dozen country music tap Duane gets in the sleeper cab, where stacks of porno tape and magazines reach the ceiling. Wesley takes the driver'  seat, Charlie, the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What part of Dixie are you from, Duane?

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Georgia. In case I didn't tell you, it's cash only, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: We can live with that.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'm a Yankee, myself. Massachusetts. Duane passes two videos to Wesley.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Here's Ghengis Kunt and The Demilitarized Zone. Get it? (laughs) They're Korean, so they're pretty hot.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You know, it's interesting. The South lost the Civil War, but they still seem to get all the glory.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Huh? 43.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Jeb Stuart, Stonewall Jackson, Jefferson Davis - they're all losers in my book. Charlie smiles. Duane stops digging through the videotape

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: The fuck you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Even Robert E. Lee was a loser.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: (to Wesley) He goin' crazy on us, or what?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Did you know the most brutal, inhumane prison of the entire war was in Georgia?

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Really. And where was that, old man?  52 53

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Andersonville. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They did horrible things to men there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chloe is curled up on her white leather sofa, cowering as Lonnie hovers over her accusingly.

dialogues.speaker: LONNIE
dialogues.text: I think you better tell me what's going on here, Chloe.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I just feel... funny about what we did.

dialogues.speaker: LONNIE
dialogues.text: (laughs) You feel guilty? Let me remind you of something, sweetheart. You're in this up to those fabulous eyes of yours. Understand? The camera holds on her face for a melodramatic beat Chloe's trapped, and she knows it. PULL BACK to reveal Betty lying on the bed in her motel r out cold. 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flag poles over the CB unit are bare. Duane is in the sleeper cab, his forearms bound to his thighs with duct t A telltale piece of Confederate red fabric hangs out of h mouth. There is a purplish bruise on his forehead. He's quiet, but glowering at his captors.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So, at a rest stop outside Logansport you noticed that two guys were slipping something extra in one of your cars, and you decided to see what it was. Then you figured you'd take this valuable commodity and go into business yourself, even though it didn't belong to you. But you needed a crackerjack salesman to move it, so you made the biggest mistake of your short life and chose Del. Sound right so far?  Duane nods. CHARLIE (cont'd) Del's dead, by the way. I sent him to the Great Beyond.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Actually, I scalped him, and then you killed him. Duane narrows his eyes in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Exactly. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, the one thing I don't get is that we checked all the Buicks on that lot. Four '97 LeSabres and nothing in 'em. Duane smiles mockingly.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ohhh ... There weren't four, were there? Charlie reaches up above the visor and pulls down a rumpl manifest. He leafs through it. CHARLIE (cont'd) There were five, damn it! I should have known! ! Goddamn... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what happened to the fifth car? 45. Duane shrugs his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know you're going to die, don't you, Duane? (Duane nods) And you really don't know where that other LeSabre is, do you? Duane shakes his head. Charlie sighs, resigned. CHARLIE (cont'd) He's telling the truth. He doesn't know.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Should I kill him now?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wait. Any last words, General Lee?  54 Duane nods emphatically. Wesley pulls the Confederate fla out of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Suck my dick, you Yankee piece of shit. He spits in Wesley's face. Charlie has to restrain Wesley

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: God, I admire that. Ya see that, Wesley? That's why they get all the glory. Charlie climbs down from the big rig and heads across the parking lot. The Town Car is parked near the adjacent mot just a few spaces away from Betty's LeSabre. With a furious calm Wesley wipes his face, then takes out can of lighter fluid, sets it on the dash and looks at Du

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: ..why'd you spit on me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie pulls the Town Car alongside Duane's rig and drum the steering wheel impatiently. It begins to rain. There are flashes of LIGHTNING in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Come on, Wesley, three shots. A FLASH OF ORANGE FLAME ignites inside Duane's cab. Charl sighs. Finally, THREE DULL THUDS reverberate from inside. Wesley climbs down clutching a videotape and gets in the 46. CHARLIE (cont'd) What the hell was that, another statement?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Well, no one ever spit in my face before. Especially some cracker fuck.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You have to rise above it. The professionals rise above that kind of thing... As they drive away FLAMES are beginning to dance inside t cab.  55 56 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FLICKERING LIGHT of the TV screen is the only light. Betty lies asleep on the bed. The NEWS comes on and she starts to stir as

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER
dialogues.text: small town of Fair Oaks ... has left people shaken ... owner-manager of Sizemore Motors Betty sits up. On the TV screen is a shot of Del as Juliu Caesar from one of his commercials.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER
dialogues.text: (cont'd) police are still investigating. She blinks at the screen, confused, as the next story com on, Betty reaches for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ballard is doing paperwork. Roy is asleep on a nearby ben A DEPUTY picks up a ringing phone and hands it to Ballard

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Sheriff, it's Betty Sizemore, on two!

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: SHHH!... (Whispering) BETTY? WHERE ARE

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I'm in a motel. Has something happened to Del? Did he do something stupid?

dialogues.speaker: I'M THROUGH TALKING NOW
dialogues.text: She hangs up. HEADLIGHTS sweep across the curtains, start her.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 58
dialogues.text: Betty crosses the border from Texas into New Mexico. She grips the wheel intently, driving for all she's worth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty's blue Corsica sits surrounded by yellow police tap Half a dozen COPS mill around. To one side are several REPORTERS and PHOTOGRAPHERS, Roy included. A FEW RESIDENT mill around in the background. A stack of pictures of Betty sit on a makeshift table.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Who witnessed Ms. Sizemore driving here?

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: The Assistant Manager, Mr. Wylie.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: But he couldn't identify the male passenger? 48.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Only to say he was wearing green.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What if the killers didn't see her? You published her picture - you're gonna get her killed!

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: No, we're bringing the community into the effort to find her.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You're lying!  61

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: I spoke to Betty Sizemore yesterday. (the reporters hush) That's right. There's no doubt in my mind, folks... she's on the run. Whether or not she's mixed up in all this remains to be seen...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: That's bullshit, Sheriff! You think she's a suspect!

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: I'd like to apologize for our local boy. He's been in love with Betty since the fifth grade, y'see. He means well, but he's in over his head on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of a headline in the Wichita Eagle: "EYE WITNE TO BRUTAL MURDER MISSING" over a picture of Betty. Charli one of MANY CUSTOMERS reading a copy. Wesley is plowing through a stack of pancakes.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: So how do we know that car's still in Fair Oaks?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We don't. But a '97 Le Sabre'll be easy to find if it's here, town this size... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he gave his wife some car as a gift, remember? Charlie turns the page for emphasis and studies Betty's features. 49. CHARLIE (cont'd) This is bad, Wesley. Very, very bad. Wesley happily adds three strips of bacon brought by A WAITRESS, who wears a button with the word "Missing" over Betty's face. CHARLIE (cont'd) extremely bad. Wesley finally looks up, directly at the picture of Betty CHARLIE (cont'd)  Did you hear what I said? Wesley nods, his mouth stuffed with food. CHARLIE (cont'd) Maybe you don't appreciate the gravity of this situation. It's bad enough that we don't have what we came here for. It's worse that we don't know where it is. And now this. (points at the headline) This was supposed to be my last job. I already put the deposit down on my boat. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you eat at a time like this? I get nauseous just watching you...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I can eat because I know we didn't kidnap that woman. I can eat because they aren't looking for us. And I can eat ‘cause I'm fucking hungry... (off Charlie's look) relax. She's gonna end up on a milk carton and that's about it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I hope you're right...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I know I am. Let's just do what we gotta do here, and get the fuck gone. They sit for a moment in silence. Wesley swallowing witho chewing and Charlie studying Betty's photo.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: She got out of town awfully fast. And wasn't she quiet in that house? I think most women would have screamed, don't you? I know they would've... (BEAT)
We could be dealing with a cunning, ruthless woman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue Ann opens her front door to find Wesley standing befo her. It's a new Wesley: glasses, conservative suit, and a convincingly humble manner.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rogers? I'm Dwight Campbell, with Neighborly Life Insurance. I'm looking for Betty Sizemore.

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: I wish I could help you, but I can't. Wesley is hit by a flying action figure. He doesn't flinc Kids run by.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Aren't they precious? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, she has a substantial death benefit coming to her from the tragic loss of her husband. Does she have any relatives in the area?

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: No. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, her grandparents are down in Oklahoma, but that's it...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I see. And are you in touch with Mrs. Sizemore?

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: No. But I'm taping her show every day so she can watch it when she comes back.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Her show?

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: "A Reason to Love." Wesley's eyes light up. He can't help himself.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I see. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Chloe testify? 51.

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: (reassuring) I don't think she will. She's a slut, but I just don't think she's that mean. Jasmine'll bring her around...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Jasmine... Do you have yesterday's show on tape, by any chance?  63 Sue Ann holds the door open, smiling, and Wesley enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie nurses a cup of coffee at the counter while talki to Darlene. His Federal Marshall's badge rests on the counter. Shehands him two photos of Betty taken at her birthday celebration. In one she's holding the cardboard David Ravell. The other, a closeup shot.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: and how long did she work here?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Oh, five years, give or take.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hmm... you two in high school together?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Aren't you a sweetheart... no, not quite. Anyway, she's been with us awhile.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: But she wanted more out of life, right?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: No... she just wanted something outta life. Anything. And with Del, she wasn't getting nothing. That's her husband, Del. I'm sorry about what happened and all, but that's the way I feel about all of this...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I see. (holding up photos) May I?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: If it helps bring her back, be my guest... 52.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thank you for your cooperation. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one more thing... did she ever talk about getting rich?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: who doesn't? Darlene tries to smile and returns to the kitchen. Charl studies the snapshots, comparing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wesley is in bed on top of Joyce, humping her slowly.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: and what kind of car does she drive?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Well, she wanted a LeSabre, but Del made her use that blue Corsica... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, is this what you boys'd call ‘pumping me for information?! Joyce GIGGLES as Wesley stops moving.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Did you say LeSabre?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Look, she didn't kill Del over no car if that's what you're thinking.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: But she could have taken one, right? With her knees, Joyce prods him into humping her again.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Maybe, but I don't think she had the nerve. I know her. And I'ma pretty good judge of character... Joyce reaches for a cigarette on the nightstand and takes deep drag. Wesley closes his eyes and turns away, offende

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: yeah, I can see that. 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty drives along a lonely stretch of highway that slowl reveals a desert town in the distance.  66

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big ol' place. Lots of wood and red leather. Betty rushes in as the clock on the wall reads 2:58. The Town Drunk, MERLE, is alone at the bar watching "Bass Masters" on a h TV screen. In front of him is a remote control. A FEW OTHERS at tables. Betty sidles up to the bar and sits down. She looks at Merle, at the clock, at the remote.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Would you mind very much if I changed the channel at three o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: MERLE
dialogues.text: Yes. He BURPS, then finally looks at her with bleary eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Please? It's very important to me. "A Reason to Love" comes on at three around here. He ignores her. Betty puts her wallet on the bar. BETTY (cont'd) I'll give you money. Merle SLAMS his hand down on the bar, scaring her.

dialogues.speaker: ARE YOU DEAF
dialogues.text: It's 3:01. ELLEN DRABER, 40's, appears behind the bar, lo at the clock and takes the remote from Merle. She changes the channel to "A Reason to Love" as the opening titles e Betty can't believe it. Merle smiles at her wickedly. MERLE (cont'd) Please keep it down, it's time for "A Reason to Love..." 54.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: That's real funny. Why don't you have another drink?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: What's the matter here?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I begged him to let me put that on!  67 68

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: He's a prick. Merle?... You're a prick. MERLE grunts in reply. Ellen turns back to Betty.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So you're into "Reason," too? Finally, someone civilized! I'm Ellen, what can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Betty. I'll take a Miller, if you got it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chloe paces in front of her white sofa, a matching white telephone in her hand. She looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What's that bitch up to now? We hear the BEEP TONE of an answering machine.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Lonnie? It's Chloe. We need to talk I don't think I can go through with this. She hangs up. The camera stays on her for a melodramatic beat of introspection as we GO TO COMMERCIAL.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Do you have a phone? Ellen swings a phone up onto the bar.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: If it's long distance you can leave me a buck when you're done. Betty dials 55.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Sue Ann? It's Betty. I just wanted to let you know I'm okay ... Huh?) I'm at the Canyon Ranch Bar in (looks at Ellen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phoenix...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Shut up, Merle... Williams.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Williams, Arizona. About halfway there, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue Ann is in her kitchen, ignoring the pleas of all thre children.

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: Halfway where? You've gotta come home. We've been worried sick about you. Are you alright?
