dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Sue Ann, I thought you of all people would back me up on this, you know what Del's like. How did he take my note?

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: Betty, honey, listen to me. A man came by from Mutual Life Insurance. He says you've got money comin' to you from Del's policy. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Del's life insurance policy-- Are you with me?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "A REASON TO LOVE" comes back on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Tell Del I'm sorry. I left so quick, but I need to do this.

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Do what? 56.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: 71 72 I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Betty! Listen to me! Del is Betty hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is at a bar staring into his drink. Lonnie is with

dialogues.speaker: LONNIE
dialogues.text: How you holding up, amigo?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I just wish I knew why she's doing it.

dialogues.speaker: LONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Women are an unsolved mystery.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: If that little weasel ever walked in here I wouldn't serve him.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'd slap his face.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'd kick him in the nuts, if I thought he had any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are two empty beer bottles in front of Betty. The T MUSIC and CLOSING CREDITS of "A Reason to Love" are playi Betty pushes the phone back across the bar.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Where you headed, Betty?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Los Angeles, California.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: And you called your friend, and she's telling you not to go? (Betty nods) When I went to Europe my friends told me I was crazy. 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Europe? The Europe? (laughs) This is my first time out of Kansas.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I should call you Dorothy. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I left here I went straight to Italy. Everybody told me not to go. But I wanted to go to Rome ever since I saw Audrey Hepburn in "Roman Holiday," and goddamnit, I went.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Did you love it?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Sure I loved it! It was great. Ellen rinses a few glasses as she talks to Betty.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something. I got groped by these Tunisian guys who thought I was a slut for wearing shorts, it was hotter than stink the whole time, and I got some kind of weird gum disease from the water. Plus, it ended my marriage--

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: That's horrible!

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: No, he was a toad. Even more of a toad than Merle... I just wear the ring to keep the flies away. Rome was the best thing I ever did, because I DID IT! And I swear to you, it changed me. I've been to Rome, Italy! I sat every morning at the Cafe Sistina and had my cappuccino, and watched the pilgrims walk to mass, and no one can ever take that away from me. Betty leans across the bar conspiratorially. She looks at Merle to make sure he won't hear her.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I left my husband two days ago.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Really? 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting back with my ex-fianc. He proposed to me right around here, so I guess this is just sort of a sentimental stop...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Wait, I thought you said you'd never been outta Kansas...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh. I mean, except for that. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. I'm trading in a car dealer for a heart specialist, so that's pretty good...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Nice move. Cedars Sinai?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: No. Loma Vista.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (laughs) I s'pose his name's David Ravell.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (truly shocked) How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: What's his real name?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Dr. David Ravell.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: You mean... George McCord, the actor?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: No, I mean David Ravell. He's a surgeon. Ellen looks at Betty.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know, we just watched him together, remember? Up there on the TV. (off Betty's earnest look) Good God Almighty ... You're serious. I've heard about people like you. Ellen whistles, wipes the bar down to buy a few seconds. Merle looks over at Betty, then catches Ellen's eye.  59.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Piss off, Merle. (to Betty) So how you gonna find him, Betty?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I'll go to the Hospital.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: What if you can't find him? What if you get out there, and nothing's the way you thought it was gonna be?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Like Rome?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Worse.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: You made out alright.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, but at least I knew Rome was gonna be there when I arrived... Ellen walks to the end of the bar and starts rinsing glas After a beat, Betty gets up and moves down close to her.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Ellen, this is the biggest thing I've ever done, but I've gotta do it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: You take care of yourself then, Betty, and don't let anybody stop you...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: To tell you the truth, I can't believe I've made it this far. It may not be Europe, but I just know there's something special out there for me... Ellen looks into Betty's eyes - sees the innocence, the h and cue the the enthusiasm - and has to look away. Betty takes it as her to leave. She smiles, puts two dollars on the bar near phone and leaves. Ellen stands perfectly still, watching door.

dialogues.speaker: MERLE
dialogues.text: What planet is she from? 60.  73 74 75

dialogues.speaker: DAY 73
dialogues.text: Betty approaches the GRAND CANYON, driving slowly along t South Rim, searching for a specific spot. Finally, she pu over abruptly. This is it. We can tell by the joy in her expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty walks to the rail and gazes out at the canyon. Turn her head slowly, as if expecting it, she sees DAVID RAVEL leaning on the rail about twenty feet away, clutching a bouquet of roses. Betty starts toward him... he starts toward her... A magi moment... Shattered when a black sedan appears, inching i way along. She freezes. David vanishes, and An ELDERLY MAN helps his wife out of the car and snaps he picture in front of the canyon. Betty moves away.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT 75
dialogues.text: Charlie and Wesley drive across Kansas farm country.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So she gets rid of the asshole and is set for life in the same day.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: You think so? Joyce says she's timid.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Joyce was screwing Del.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: among others.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'd say that about torches her credibility, wouldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, if the wife's trying to sell it she'll fuck up. She's an amateur, just like Del was. The CAR PHONE RINGS. Charlie answers. 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe... (into phone) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Is this Neighborly Life Insurance?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sorry, you've got the wrong number. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, I see Betty as a Midwestern Stoic type. Ice water in her veins. A clear thinker. Probably a Swede or a Finn.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: A 'Finn?' What is a Finn?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You should read more. Listen to me. I think this woman was waiting for a chance to do this, and we gave it to her. She kept to herself for years, living with a pompous asshole. Then she sees her opportunity, and BOOM! - she leaves that little mudpatch in the dust. These heartlanders can't figure it out, ‘cause that's not their sweet little Betty. Hah! We've been tracking her for, what, three days and I already understand her better'n most the people in that shitty little burg. Charlie pulls out the close-up photo and studies it. CHARLIE (cont'd) Betty, Betty, Betty...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: So what the fuck's a Finn?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, for Chrissakes. It just means the kind of person who can eat shit for a long time without complaining, then cut their momma's throat and go dancing the same night.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Like... us? 62.  76

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No,... like a worthy adversary, Wesley. Like a very worthy adversary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy approaches his fish tank cautiously. He leans down an looks at the piranha as a TV commercial ends and "A Reaso Love" comes on. He then returns to his computer, struggling to find the r words and to type them with only one hand. He types a little, stares at the screen, then deletes an entire sent one character at a time, hammering on the ‘Delete’ key. H glances up at the television as the words 'Chloe' and ‘Lonnie’ are repeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy and Sue Ann go straight to Ballard's office, where th find him at his desk eating lunch out of tupperware containers. He wears a napkin tucked into his shirt-top.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: What the hell do you want?... Hey, Sue Ann, what's up?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: We think we know where Betty is.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Ah, shit... Do I have to hear this now?

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: What's with the tupperware, Elden, did Meredith run outta baggies?

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: No reason to get a plate dirty.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I see you're sticking to the diet Betty put you on...

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Worry about your own goddamn lunch!

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (excited; to Sue Ann) Tell him what you told me. 63.

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: Betty is a big, big fan of the soap opera, "A Reason to Love." Look... She tosses a copy of "Soap Opera Digest" on the desk. Bal ignores it and keeps eating.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Why do I need to see this? Did he ask you to...?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Listen! I saw 'Chloe' and 'Lonnie' on T.V. They're television characters.

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: Betty's in love with Dr. David Ravell, from the show. What if she's out in Los Angeles looking for him? The actor, I mean...

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: That's the dumbest thing I've ever heard.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, she called Sue Ann yesterday from Arizona.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: She said she was in Arizona, did she?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Yes!!

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: You people are even more stupid than I thought. The woman's on the run and she's gonna just phone in her location?

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: Come on, Elden, she's not on the run. Couldn't you at least call the Los Angeles Police Department?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You gotta do that much.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm the law. I don't gotta do nothing...  78 79 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lincoln pulls into the dusty, overgrown driveway and front yard of a derelict farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The remains of pie and coffee on the table, Charlie and Wesley kick back with JERROLD BLAINE and his wife ELIZABE both in their 80's. Photos of Betty at various ages lie scattered in front of them. Charlie holds up a picture of a young Betty in ballerina costume posing at the barre. He studies it intently.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: This is Betty at twelve.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Very graceful. Perfect form.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Betty was a lovely child.

dialogues.speaker: JERROLD
dialogues.text: And she always had such spirit! But, after her mother died...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Would you say she was ambitious?

dialogues.speaker: JERROLD
dialogues.text: Oh, there's no tellin’ what that girl could've accomplished, and she never had it easy. Never really had a childhood... caring for her father, going to school. Charlie admires a photo of Betty, around 18 years old. He continues to rummage through a box of collectibles, pocke a small child's diary when it is convenient.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wise beyond her years, I'm sure, and such poise, too. (quietly) very, very impressive...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Well, then, did you ever get any indication that she wanted to leave her  husband? 65.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I don't like talking bad about the dead, but now that he's gone I can tell you she put up with things in that marriage I wouldn't have. And yes, she, of all people, was the one who defended him. And that's why what that sheriff said makes me so angry.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: If anyone had paid to have that husband of hers killed, it would have been me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (taking her hand) Mrs. Blaine? I can tell you right now, without a doubt, that your granddaughter is alive, and did not kill Del Sizemore.

dialogues.speaker: JERROLD
dialogues.text: You've got to be missing a piece of your soul to kill someone. That's not our Betty...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: (defensive) why do you think you have to be missing a piece of your soul to kill somebody?

dialogues.speaker: JERROLD
dialogues.text: Because it ain't natural, young man.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Killing's totally natural. It's dying that isn't natural...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (covering) My partner's still young, Mr. Blaine, and he loves his job. (laughs) He'd like to kill all the criminals himself! (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, if Betty was running from someone, where do you think she'd go?  80-82 83 84

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Betty drives through Boyle Heights - East L.A., holding a and checking street signs. She is wearing a brand new Nurse's uniform. Up ahead, she sees the hillside complex L.A. County/USC Hospital. Hurriedly, she pulls over and checks herself in the visor mirror. She is underwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: God... I still look like a waitress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHIEF NURSE, a large, dynamic woman in her 50's, face Betty across her desk.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF NURSE
dialogues.text: Of course, I don't know every doctor who works here...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Dr. Ravell's the finest surgeon on the staff. You must know him. He's incredibly handsome, gentle, considerate. He's being sued for sexual assault right now, but-— (Off Chief Nurse's look) It's not true. He was set up.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF NURSE
dialogues.text: Well, I certainly would have heard about that.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Of course, he's only here two days a week. He's also on staff over at Loma Vista.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF NURSE
dialogues.text: I don't think I know that hospital.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: It's in a very pretty area that gets a lot of sun, has palm trees out front, mountains in the background...  85

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF NURSE
dialogues.text: Really? You've just described all of Southern California. The Chief Nurse looks at Betty for a moment, then stands abruptly, signaling the end of the interview. 67.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF NURSE
dialogues.text: (cont'd) Well, I'm sorry, but I can't even consider you without references or a resume. And frankly, I don't know how you could have forgotten them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On her way down the hall Betty passes a patient's room wh the sound of A PERSON MOANING stops her. She can't help b go inside. A TV plays commercials. AN OLDER WOMAN lies in bed, alone and staring at the ceil Betty looks around and notices several arrangements of flowers on a deserted nightstand. She brings them over to the older woman's bedside, positions them, then gently strokes her head.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: There... you rest now. The woman's eyes flutter. She is disoriented at first, th calms as she adjusts to the comforting sight of Betty. Be takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER WOMAN
dialogues.text: Who... who're you?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I'm... I'm Nurse Betty. The woman smiles serenely at this and begins to drift off Betty checks her monitors as the opening credits of "A Re to Love" begin to play. She glances up at the doorway at the same moment and sees David Ravell standing at the entrance. He checks the char on the door, smiles warmly at Betty and then moves off. I flash, Betty is up and after him. The THEME MUSIC is her private soundtrack as she checks o every man in surgical scrubs, looking for David Ravell. Then... She sees him. In all his glory at the end of a  86 87 corridor walking away from her. Betty gives chase. She gains steadily on him, her heart racing. As they near Emergency the NOISE LEVEL picks up. He stops at the nurses' station. Betty closes the gap. Sh starts to run.
He turns to face her ... It's not David Ravell. BETTY (cont'd) Sorry, I thought you were someone else. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know Dr. David Ravell? The man shakes his head. Betty keeps going, looking aroun it's incredible - the size, the activity, the intensity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOZENS OF PATIENTS lie on gurneys awaiting treatment in a holding area. It's still more intense at the entrance: VOICES talking back and forth urgently, POLICE OFFICERS, CIVILIANS, DOCTORS AND NURSES converging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIVE AMBULANCES unload patients at the same time. At that moment a group of TWENTY JAPANESE HOSPITAL ADMINISTRATORS reaches the E.R. portion of their tour. A WHITE MERCEDES tears up the ramp and SCREECHES to a sto A YOUNG MAN in gang colors is pushed out, bleeding heavil A DOCTOR runs at the Mercedes to head it off, yelling indignantly. The car plows right into him and takes off. Another ambulance crests the ramp, lights flashing. The Mercedes SLAMS into it head-on. NURSES AND DOCTORS run in the parking lot. A GANGBANGER gets out of the Mercedes, d and wobbly. He pulls a pistol. Everyone dives for cover. The Mercedes driver is unconscious. The driver of the sma up ambulance is slumped over the wheel. The rear doors fl open, and a young Hispanic woman, ROSA HERRERA, leaps out

dialogues.speaker: SOMEBODY HELP US
dialogues.text: Doctors and nurses work on patients and try to get to the injured doctor, but the kid with the gun keeps them away. SECURITY GUARDS draw their guns and scream at him to dro ROSA (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: WHY ISN'T ANYBODY HELPING US
dialogues.text: (to gunman in Spanish) Hey, you little shit! If I had a gun I'd shoot you right now! The loading area is jammed with panicked people. Doctors nurses creep out of the hospital on all fours, trying to 69. low. No one is getting to Rosa, whose frantic eyes find Betty. They look right at each other. ROSA (cont'd) What are you standing there for?! Betty walks toward her calmly, indifferent to the danger Rosa pulls the gurney out of the ambulance herself. A PARAMEDIC lies unconscious inside. ROSA (cont'd) You gotta help him, he's hurt bad!! On the gurney is a YOUNG MAN with a chest wound, nearly d from blood loss. A DOCTOR appears and quickly examines hi while keeping one eye on the gunman. He looks up at Betty

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Forget it! He doesn't have a chance. Help us over here. The doctor takes off. Rosa looks at Betty, crying.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Please! Betty hesitates, then checks his pulse - he has none. She peels back the bandages over a huge chest wound.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Danny, it's gonna be all right! Betty looks at Rosa again; looks around for help - there' one. She plunges her fingers into the wound. ROSA (cont'd) (panic) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: He has no heartbeat!

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: You're hurting him!!  88 89

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I'm massaging his heart. I saw it done once.
She keeps working on him. We hear a GUNSHOT, and the kid with the pistol falls to the pavement. The loading area immediately fills with DOCTORS, NURSES and COPS.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right, we're moving him inside! Give me a hand! Rosa is shocked into motion. Together they wheel Danny to the entrance. A DOCTOR and TWO NURSES come out to take ov Betty, her white uniform now covered in blood, steps asid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOCTOR tries to calm Rosa and keep her from entering treatment area.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Is he gonna live?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: He's got a chance. Thanks to what that nurse did. They exit together as AN ADMINISTRATOR and several Japane officials approach. The Chief Nurse hovers nearby.

dialogues.speaker: ADMINISTRATOR
dialogues.text: (to Chief Nurse) Harriet? Who is that remarkable nurse?

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF NURSE
dialogues.text: That's Betty Sagamore. I hired her today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEVERAL LOW LIFES are hanging out in the lobby. When Bett  90 comes in with a bag of groceries they look up, ready to hassle her as she approaches the DESK CLERK.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: May I have my key, please? She puts the bag on the counter, revealing that the front her white uniform is covered with blood. She smiles at th low lifes, stopping them in their tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Town Car's looking a little muddy around the rims. Charlie and Wesley look tired as they wait in a seedy mot 71. room. Charlie sits near a window, reading diary entries aloud. Wesley kicks back on the bed, fast-forwarding thro "Genghis Kunt" and talking back to the screen.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Thas' it, thas' it... conquer that bitch. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time're they coming?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It's not an exact science, Wesley. He said they'll be here... My Houston contact has always been very reliable.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: And then we're gonna do her right here. Right?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You're always so coarse... "Do her right here." Let's just see what happens, okay? (reading) "I wish that I could find a way; To speak my thoughts on Mother's Day. There are no words that quite express; My gratitude or happiness. A pleasant smile perhaps a kiss; I would not fail to give her this. I'd make her glad the whole day through; By sayin' 'Mother', I love you!" P.S. I wish I could say this to my mother's face, but I can't anymore." Wesley rolls his eyes and turns up the volume. Finally a pulls up outside and Charlie snaps the book closed. He ma a quick attempt to arrange himself and motions to Wesley, turns off the tape. A WOMAN with greasy blonde hair and skinny legs shown of a short skirt comes in with another MAN. Charlie looks he over disgustedly as his face falls. CHARLIE (cont'd) Who are you?! (to the man) What the... Who the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Easy, Charlie! She's exactly who you said you were looking for.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wait, wait a minute. We have a major miscommunication here. This not Betty. This is not even close to Betty... 72.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: What the fuck're you talking about? My name's Betty...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Then I'm sorry... Wrong Betty.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here. We got another long drive ahead of us. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the fuck where I do not know, but I know it's gonna be long.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (gathering his things) Betty would never dress like that. She's not some trailer park slut!

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And she doesn't have a sewer for a mouth...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Okay, thank you, goodbye... Keep in touch...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: She's got class, and poise. Lots of poise... The man looks at Charlie, then at Wesley, who shrugs in r as he steers them out the door.  91 92

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Will you ease off on the ‘poise’ shit, you're spooking me here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief Nurse sits behind her desk. Betty faces her like a student in the principal's office, now dressed in her whi waitress uniform. She hopes no one notices.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF NURSE
dialogues.text: What you did yesterday was reckless at best. You are not an employee of this hospital! If that boy dies I don't even want to think of the lawsuit that'll follow. Are we communicating here? 73.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF NURSE
dialogues.text: Good. I'm prepared to offer you a job. You can help out in the pharmacy until your California certification and references arrive, but you are not to touch anyone. Is that totally clear? (Betty nods) Fine... The Chief Nurse gets up, and Betty follows suit.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF NURSE
dialogues.text: (cont'd) You can start tomorrow. And don't say a word about this to anyone. (studying Betty's uniform) Is that issue?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Umm... yes. Back home.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF NURSE
dialogues.text: Alright. Oh, and one more thing about what you did yesterday... Well done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny Herrera is in bed unconscious. Rosa and her MOTHER keeping vigil when Betty enters. Rosa jumps to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's Supernurse! Betty, right? Rosa hugs her and tells her mother in Spanish who Betty i ROSA (cont'd) My mother doesn't speak English. Sra. Herrera smiles at Betty and starts to cry. As she st forward, Rosa stands aside. The short, stocky woman envel Betty in a bearhug.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: No podremos olvidar lo que hizo ayer.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: (translating) We can't forget what you did yesterday How can my family ever repay you? 74.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Tell her I was just--

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Yo s que es su empleo, pero...

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: She doesn't care if it was just your job... Danny would be dead now but for you. Sra. Herrera kisses Betty's hands and smiles through her tears. Then she motions to Rosa to take her place as she goes to Danny's bedside. Betty picks up Danny's chart and reads it. ROSA (cont'd) You don't sound like you're from here.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I'm not. I just drove in from Kansas.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: So why'd you come to L.A.?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I came for love. My fianc is here.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Bravo! Mi hija no hace nada para amor...

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: You're making me look bad... My mother  93 says I wouldn't move across the street for love.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: It's something I had to do. For David.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: "David.' That's your guy. So, you staying with him? THE ICU NURSE enters and adjusts the bank of machines feeding, medicating and monitoring Danny. Betty watches w interest.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: No... I don't really know where he is yet. I'm at a hotel around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Man, that is love. 75.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Ella debe quedar contigo.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: What? Ahh, Mom says you should stay with me... Okay, yeah, why not? Betty looks at Sra. Herrera curiously.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can go get your stuff right now. I'll walk you down.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: No, that's not, I couldn't...

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Listen, when someone does the kind of thing you did, you gotta do something in return. So, you stay with me until you find your David and live happily ever after. Okay? Rosa follows Betty out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty and Rosa make their way up the stairs of a Silverla apartment house. At the sound of SCREECHING TIRES they both look down as a  94 black Lincoln Town Car drives by. Betty shudders.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: You okay? This neighborhood, you get used to it... She nods. Rosa continues to talk as they climb the many stairs that lead to her door. ROSA (cont'd) I got this apartment with a guy.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: The one you were telling me about?

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: No, this one was worse...I had to have the place sprayed when he left. Twice... He was two guys before the last one--not counting a little office thing in there, which I'm trusting you with, ‘cause if it gets out, I'm on the street... 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is neat. As well furnished as a legal assistant salary will allow. The living room is dominated by a larg glass tank filled with tropical fish. Betty checks out th space.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: It's lovely...I really like your aquarium.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, at least fish don't use your razor or pee on the seat...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Hmmm. Sounds like you've had a pretty tough go of it with men...

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Oh, I dunno...but just once I wish I'd run into a guy who noticed the Koi before my tits. Betty smiles, a little embarrassed. ROSA (cont'd) ..come on, I'll show you your room.  95

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black Lincoln Town Car is parked on a lonely stretch prairie highway. Wesley sits in the passenger seat with t door open. The RADIO is on. Charlie is on his cell phone nearby.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (into phone) No, we don't know where she is... I understand... No, we'll find her... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. He hangs up and looks out at the horizon, where huge blac storm Clouds are gathering. Then he walks slowly to the h of the car, staring at the ground in front of his feet.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: What'd they say? Can we go back to Detroit? Charlie rests his hands gently on the hood, as if conside buying the car. Wesley's MUSIC BANGS from the radio. 77.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: They said find it. Find her, find it. Finish the job you were paid to do.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Half.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: They paid us half. They still owe us half...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (disappointed) There it is again. That lousy attitude that got us here in the first place. That "make a statement," do an end zone dance, shake your ass and sue everybody in sight attitude that's dragging this whole country down the drain. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't owe us shit, Wesley! WHEN YOU

dialogues.speaker: HAVEN'T FINISHED THE GODDAMN JOB
dialogues.text: Charlie POUNDS on the hood of the car, scaring Wesley. CHARLIE (cont'd) That woman could be in any one of four states. Four big states where the deer and the antelope play, Wesley! We're not in Rhode Island!

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: AND TURN THAT FUCKING MUSIC OFF
dialogues.text: Wesley switches it off. Charlie turns his back to the car and addresses the angry clouds on the horizon. CHARLIE (cont'd) Do I deserve this? In the twilight of my career, do I deserve this? I don't think so! I've always tried to do what's right. I never took out anybody who didn't have it coming. I'ma professional! (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Worse... you're in Texas.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, I should be in FLORIDA now! If Carl hadn't gone in to get those stones removed, you wouldn't be here and I'd be on my way to the Keys. On my boat, RELAXING WITH A GLASS OF PORT!! Re-ti red! The first raindrops begin to fall. CHARLIE (cont'd) I'm very tired, Wesley! I've worked hard, and the work should be over, but IT'S NOT! This job is just beginning. (he turns around)

dialogues.speaker: GET IN THE CAR
dialogues.text: Wesley is in the car, but he's too scared to tell Charlie whose eyes are blazing. Charlie silently walks around to driver's side and gets in. He and Wesley stare at each ot over a photo of Betty, which is between them on the dash. Charlie starts the engine and snatches up the picture.  CHARLIE (cont'd) What're you thinking, girl? What's going on in that pretty little mind of yours? Huh? You can tell me... He paws at the picture, imploringly. He mutters to himsel Wesley shakes his head and stares out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty sits in an office along with a CLERK who taps away computer keyboard while she studies a printed list of nam

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I can't find Loma Vista Hospital...

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: I never heard of Loma Vista Hospital.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I don't believe this! You're the second person here who's told me that. That's like Ford saying they never heard of GM!

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Try another county... 79. He exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosa is on the phone at her desk in a law office.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Rosa...it's Betty. How do you get to this town called 'Tustin?' It's in Orange County...

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Tustin? Take the Hollywood Freeway to the Five...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The Five?

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Just look for the really crowded road and follow that.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: 98 99 Okay...oh, umm, would you mind if I borrowed some clothes?

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Huh? Sure, look in my closet, take any dress you want! (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're still on for tonight, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty stands in a sexy pink dress, trying to decide if sh should put on a hospital gown and waits, tensing each tim she hears a voice from the hallway. Finally, the DOORKNOB BEGINS TO TURN. A man's hand and the bottom of a white sleeve appear. The door swings open and a silver-haired, bespectacled DOCTOR his mid-60's enters. The nametag on his white coat reads “DAVID RAVELL, M.D."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tasteful jazz, plenty of red leather booths. Betty winds way through a PACKED CROWD, passing out small white cards Rosa spots her and goes over to meet her. 80.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: You made it! Hey, that looks great on you. 'S classy... (BEAT) So, how'd it go today? You find him?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Ummm...no, no. Different 'Ravell.' Rosa starts to lead her to the bar. BETTY (cont'd) You know, the more I think about it, this really isn't David's kind of place.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? This bar is packed with professional people! (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody says if you're going to get married, this is the spot to meet someone... Luckily, I'm currently off men, so I've got the luxury of not giving a shit.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I know what you mean, I recently had some trouble with a man, a different man...and David's still getting over Leslie. (off Rosa's look) His wife.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: He has a wife?!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Had. She died in a car accident last year. She was decapitated.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: God, that's awful!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: It may not have been an accident. They never did find her head...

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Her ‘head’?! You're making this up...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: No, no! Well, see, she was having an affair with a Russian diplomat who I believe was mixed up with the Mafia... 81.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Jesus, I thought my love life was crazy... Rosa and Betty are sitting in a booth, talking over drink The place is a little quieter now. ROSA (cont'd) so, we'll hit the library first and fan out from there. They've got all the L.A. phone books, plus medical directories... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not gonna let him hide from you any more, okay? I'm making this my personal mission.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: David isn't hiding from me, I left him standing at the altar six years ago and now I'm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck the details, they're always to blame... Look, too many of these guys duck out on us, especially after they become doctors or lawyers. I see it at my company all day long! So I'm just gonna make sure you get your, you know, fairy tale ending or whatever... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of us should.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Rosa, I can't believe you're doing all this for me...thank you. Rosa glances over to see Betty pass a business card to A WAITER who checks on them. When he is safely gone, Rosa touches Betty on the sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Hey, how 'bout a card for me? What is that? (takes one, reads) "Please call if you have any information on David Ravell." This is my phone number! How many of these have you given out?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: How many men have I talked to? 82.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Jesus! They're all gonna be calling me!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: You said in L.A., anything goes.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: I was talking about what you could wear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Town Car's parked on a barren stretch of desert highw white smoke billowing from the hood. Half a mile ahead Charlie and Wesley are walking in the sweltering heat. They're in their shirtsleeves, drenched in sweat as the s beats down on them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: See, in a LeSabre Betty's probably getting twenty-two, maybe twenty-five  miles to the gallon, where we're topping out at fifteen. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's probably all cool and fresh, and comfortable in that nice air-conditioned car right now. Wesley wipes the sweat from his eyes and trudges on in silence. Charlie takes out a photo of Betty and speaks to CHARLIE (cont'd) You don't look comfortable here. That's "cause you don't like being the center of attention, do you? Nah. You're like me.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: What the hell's the matter with you? Wesley grabs the photo, tears it in half and tosses it. T he starts walking. Charlie is stunned for a moment, but recovers quickly. He finds the pieces and stuffs them in pocket, then catches up to Wesley.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That was a really shitty thing to do.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I'm sick of looking at her mother-fucking face. A beat... they walk for a moment. 83.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Don't talk like that. She's my last one, Wesley, my final target. (to photo) Don't you realize your special, that you represent something? This is too much. Wesley explodes.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: What? What does she represent?! What could some cornbread white bitch from Kansas who's dragging our sorry asses up and down the Louisiana Purchase possibly mean to you?!! I'd just love to know...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I dunno... something. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is she doing this to me? Why?...

dialogues.speaker: 102A
dialogues.text: I don't know, but when we find her she's gonna die for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lincoln Town Car is raised up high on the hydraulic j Wesley is at a pay phone out front.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Can you describe her to me? Okay... Yeah, that sounds like her... Thanks. He hangs up and goes into the garage, where he addresses Town Car above him. WESLEY (cont'd) They found her in Vegas. No answer. WESLEY (cont'd) Perfect match on the description.

dialogues.speaker: ON CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Lying across the front seat taping the reassembled photo Betty to the dash. Charlie's beginning to come apart. His hair is uncombed and his clothes are wrinkled. His eyes h a thousand-yard stare. 84.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like she's with the buyer Del lined up. Charlie pulls himself up on the door and looks down.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How'd they describe her?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: You know, blonde, thin, whatever...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Not so fast! Slower... 'blonde, thin', yes... Did they say she had style? A kind of grace or anything?  Wesley rolls his eyes, then goes straight to the levers controlling the hydraulic jack.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: (to mechanic) How do I get this fucking thing down?

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: I wouldn't if I were you. He got pretty upset when I tried it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MERCEDES LOPEZ, early 40's, impeccably dressed, enters he office loaded down with a bulging briefcase and a stack o files under her arms. (The entire scene is in Spanish.)

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: What do you think my father would do if I told him I didn't want to be a lawyer anymore?

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Probably the same thing my mom would do if I got engaged... have a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: So how's it going with your new roomie? What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Betty. It's O.K. except I'm worn out. We spent all weekend looking for her 85. doctor-boy. How can a big time heart guy leave no trace of himself?

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: So tell her to settle for the old one in Orange County.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: She's gonna have to 'cause I'm out of ideas.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Maybe we're suing him for malpractice. What's his name again?

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: David Ravell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, that sounds so familiar. Ravell, Ravell... where's he out of?

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: I'm not sure now. She said he used to be over at Loma Vista. I never heard of it.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Loma Vista? (laughs) You mean like the guy on "A Reason to Love?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosa enters, tosses her purse on the table and goes strai to the VCR. Written in magic marker on a video is "A Reas to Love, Apr. 23." The tape Sue Ann gave to Betty. She pops it in and turns it on. The OPENING TITLES start The characters appear ... one is an impossibly handsome m over the title "DOCTOR DAVID RAVELL."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty working at a desk in the pharmacy. The same clerk a before busies himself at another counter. Rosa appears at the glass partition and raps urgently on it.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Guess who I saw today.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Who? 86.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Doctor David Ravell.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: What? Where was he?!

dialogues.speaker: ON TELEVISION
dialogues.text: (off Betty's puzzled look) Cut the shit, will you! A BEAT. Rosa SLAMS the videotape down on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Either you're making a fool out of me  because you get off on it, or you got serious problems. Which one is it?!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I have no idea what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Shhh! I heard you the first time.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: (suddenly calm) I spent my weekend looking for someone who does - not - exist. I should have been here at the hospital with my brother, but I was with you.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: If you didn't want to do it, you should have said so! Is this about gas money?

dialogues.speaker: IT'S NOT ABOUT GAS MONEY
dialogues.text: (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a thing for an actor on a stupid white soap opera, and we searched all over town for his character! Not the actor - whose name is George, by the way. His character! Rosa stands over Betty, fuming.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Are you having a nervous breakdown? Rosa SCREAMS and smacks her hand on the glass as Betty watches. SEVERAL PEOPLE in a nearby lounge look up. Rosa stares at them until they look away. 87. BETTY (cont'd) Why'd you help me in the first place?

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: I helped you because I'm an idiot! Ask my mother, I love it when people take advantage of me! I TRUSTED YOoU!! I

dialogues.speaker: HE IS REAL
dialogues.text: Betty tries to return to her work but Rosa confronts her  106

dialogues.speaker: 106A
dialogues.text: loudly. The nearby VISITORS and STAFF pretend to be busy.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: You need help, Betty! Even if this is your idea of a joke, you need SERIOUS

dialogues.speaker: HELP
dialogues.text: (walking away - to herself) Necesitas un mdico! Pront simo!

dialogues.speaker: ON BETTY
dialogues.text: fuming in her humiliation. After a moment, Rosa reappears the window. ROSA (cont'd) I'm not going back on our arrangement. My word is good, and my family owes you. But I think it's best for both of us if you get your own place as soon as you can.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy and Joyce approach the door to the trailer/office. Sh takes out her key, then stops. It's been padlocked and ba with yellow police tape, as is the whole lot. Roy pulls h on the lock, then starts looking around.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: You're wastin' your time, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Look Joyce, I need your key to the files, not advice, okay? This is a complex case. 88. Roy works on opening a side window.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Nothin' complex about it. Del's dead, Betty's gone. She's probably dead, too.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You'd like that wouldn't you? You've hated Betty since you were in Pep Squad together...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... before that.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Ahh, I hate this town! Places like this just make you small... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have never come back here after college.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Blah - blah - blah... Hurry up, will ya, I got a date tonight... Roy forces the glass open and starts to squirm through th window as The color Joyce watches. JOYCE (cont'd) I don't know what you think you'll find, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: ROY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Names, a phone number, something... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Ballard told me that the guy who brought the missing car down from Detroit was murdered, but do you see him doing anything about it? If Ballard wasn't such a stubborn ass, I wouldn't have to be breaking in here... drains from Joyce's face.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: ROY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The driver was killed. I think there's a connection--

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (starting to cry) No, about... Are you talking about Duane Cooley? 89.

dialogues.speaker: ROY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah. Why, you know him?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (crying) Know him? We were gonna get married! He was gonna leave his wife for me! Fuck!!...  Joyce begins to sob at the side of the trailer as Roy shimmies through the window frame. Suddenly, Ballard is there, weapon cocked and placed roug into Roy's privates. Joyce backs away.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: I know you don't use them, but if you wanna keep ‘em you'll back out of there slowly...

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT 106B
dialogues.text: Roy is in the rear of the car, handcuffed to the screen dividing the front seat from the back. Ballard is driving

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Come on, Elden, think about it. The driver, all them trunks standing open like that... something's going on here!

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: I know that...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Well, do something, then, damnit!

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: You watch your mouth when you're in a goddamn county vehicle... You don't think I see what's going on? Del, now this Cooley fella, both of 'em mixed up with Joyce... 'S not no conspiracy, not some episode off the X-Files... 's just a crime of passion, plain and simple. Betty's on some kind'a pre-minstral rampage, that's what is going on here. A moment of silence as they drive.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Oww... Did you have to make these things so tight? 90.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: No, I didn't have to. He grins at Roy in the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercedes Lopez arrives at the office and stops at Rosa's desk. (The entire scene is in Spanish)

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Hey... Is Betty still trying to find that soap opera guy?

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah... Man, I'd love to find that actor just to see the look on her face, watch her bubble burst in mid-air. Mercedes hands her two tickets to a benefit.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Here's your needle... He's supposed to make an appearance here tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty's lying on her bed reading "Modern Nurse". The L.A. Times Classifieds are open on the bed. Rosa looks in.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I'm looking... just taking a tiny break.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: This is crazy. I come home, you go to your room. You go in the kitchen, I go to my room. It's stupid. Betty nods in agreement. ROSA (cont'd) So what do you say? Can we be friends?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: . okay. Rosa smiles and starts looking at the tickets in her hand BETTY (cont'd) What are those for? 91.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Oh, it's a charity dinner. The money goes to a good cause, but I don't have  anybody to go with...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Umm... Rosa exits for a moment, then reappears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: ...you hungry at all?

dialogues.speaker: LATE AFTERNOON 109
dialogues.text: The car is covered in dust and mud from the road. It's wo inside: food wrappers, empty bottles, pieces of clothing, filthy windows. They've been living in it. Wesley's driving now. Charlie's almost unrecognizable: a day beard, uncombed greasy hair, bloodshot eyes, rumpled clothes and an exhausted, faraway look. The photo of Bett faces him, taped to the glove box. He is reading from the diary, which he clutches like the Bible. They roar along a desert highway, passing a sign that say "Grand Canyon, This Exit. 74 Miles." Charlie looks up, marking his place.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We should go.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: We don't have time to look at a hole in the ground. We can make Vegas in four hours. This one's got to be her.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It's a very moving experience, trust me.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: No

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: One of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: No... be dark before we get there. You wanna see the Grand Canyon at night?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What difference does it make? She wasn't in Kansas City, or Houston, or Dallas. We 92. went to every goddamn place Del mentioned and no Betty. So what the hell makes you  think she's in Vegas? You think she's waiting for us with tassles on her titties? Vegas is too crass for Betty.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I said, 'No.' N-O. Charlie turns to a passage and reads aloud.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: “When I grow up I'm going to become a nurse or a veterinarian. I always want to help people and value all life, be it animal, plant or mineral..." (to Wesley) Does that sound like a goddamn showgirl to you?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Do you hear yourself right now...? Like a fucking madman... Wesley drives on stoically. The Exit comes and goes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Every American should see the Grand Canyon. Are you an American?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Yes, I am and we're not going. Act professional. Charlie stares at him, hate rising from just below the surface. He draws a nickel-plated pistol and points it at Wesley's head. Wesley looks at it and keeps on driving. Charlie knows this isn't the way to handle it. He lowers pistol.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: If you don't take the next turn for the canyon, I'm blowing my goddamn brains all over this car. He puts the pistol in his mouth and cocks it. Wesley look over, not so sure this time. LONG SHOT of the black Town Car as the turn signal comes and it eases onto a lonely dirt road. Their headlights pi out a sign that says: "Grand Canyon Fire Trail. Forestry Personnel Only." 93.  110 111

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosa and Betty approach the hotel entrance. Ahead of them black Lincoln Town Car pulls up. Headlights glint on the chrome, hitting Betty in the eye. She freezes, and Rosa b into her.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Sorry. Betty stares at the car, unable to remember what it shoul mean. Then a MAN in a tuxedo gets out. Betty moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign on an easel reads "Save the Children." Betty and R present their tickets at the door to a ballroom. Several times there is a stir near the entrance and a scattering of flashbulbs. Rosa scans the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Looking for someone?

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: You never know who you'll see. Rosa keeps looking. Finally, GEORGE McCORD - the actor wh plays DAVID RAVELL - enters. He comes in with LYLA BRANCH, late 40's, and TWO OTHER ME Several women approach George, some starry-eyed, for quic polite greetings. He's doing his job of being a soap star Rosa waits for an opening, then puts her hands on Betty's shoulders and points her at George. ROSA (cont'd) Look who's here! Betty's jaw drops. She freezes. ROSA (cont'd) What are you waiting for? ‘Talk to him! You came fifteen hundred miles for this. Rosa prods her, then Betty makes her way unsteadily towar George. When she's a few feet away he looks up. He can't help but notice her - she's beautiful. She's als looking right into his eyes. The conversation stops as he does a double take in Betty's direction. 94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I know you from...? His friends watch as George studies her face.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: ..0f course you do. (hurt) You don't remember me?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I take it I should. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: We were engaged.

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: Oh good, another one... George's friends look at each other. A few heads turn.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: But I'm the one who's sorry. Letting you go was the biggest mistake of my life. (to his friends) We were thirteen days away from getting married and ... I just got scared. It's a mistake I've had to live with for six years. But it's behind me now... (to George) And I hope you can put it behind you. I've missed you... David. George sighs with relief. His friends smile. The tension evaporates. They can handle a fanatical fan.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's very kind of you.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: The day I left you I just drove and drove. I drove all day and all that night, and I didn't go anywhere. I just kept driving. I stopped at a little country church, and the pastor let me in, and I sat--

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: in the very first pew, where we would have sat on our wedding day. 95.  Betty looks at her. So does George. LYLA (cont'd) I can't believe I remembered that, although I suppose I should. I wrote it... (to Betty) But that was seven years ago, and you're quoting it verbatim. I'm flattered... I think. Or frightened. What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Betty Sizemore. What do you mean you wrote it?

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: I'm Lyla Branch. I'm the Producer. They shake hands. ACROSS THE ROOM Rosa watches expectantl LYLA (cont'd) Alright, I admit it, you had me there. You're better than most of them, anyway...do you have a headshot?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, wait...what happened next, Betty?

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: Are you sure you want to encourage this? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're right, let's have some fun. So, what did happened next, "Betty"?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Well, David moved out here and started his residency. Then he met Leslie--

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: No, no, no. We know all that. What happened with you?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I married a car salesman. The friends laugh. Rosa watches, confused. So is Betty.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: You were dumped for a car salesman, George!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Why are you calling him George? 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah - David - tell us about this car salesman. George likes the challenge. This party isn't so boring af all.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean Fred.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: No, Del.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Right, Del. Del was one hot salesman. Of cars. He could talk anyone into anything.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: You knew Del?!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Honey, I didn't want to tell you at the time, but Del and I go way back. We went to school together. In fact, he saved my life. Two more minutes in that icy water and I would have drowned. But Del jumped in and grabbed me. We fell out of touch eventually, but I still owe him one.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: He never told me anything about...that's unbelievable!

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: Funny, that's just what I was thinking...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I can't tell you how much it hurts me to hear that you married him. His friends snicker. Rosa stares. Betty is oblivious to everything but George.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry. Life makes us do awful things sometimes. She's ready to cry. Which only inspires him all the more.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I tried to tell myself it was for the best, that there was a reason behind it. But... Del?  97.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: There was no plan! I was just young and stupid and scared!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You never gave us a chance...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I know that. I can't tell you how many times I've said that to myself in those exact words. Betty wipes her tears away as they flow freely now. Georg doesn't like seeing her cry; he tries to say something bu his friends interrupt.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey, don't... come on, I was just... you're not really crying, are you?... I was just playing along...

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: Now, look what you've done, George.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Why do they keep calling you George?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't know. Why do you keep calling me George?

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: Listen - David - It's getting late. George hesitates; Lyla sees it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (to Betty) Right, uhh...I feel terrible about this, we have a prior engagement at another party. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... I'd be honored if you'd come.

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: Yeah, bring your friend along. I'm sure you got a lot of catching up to do... Rosa watches, stunned, as Betty waves to her as she leave arm-in-arm with the man of her dreams. 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Town Car is parked near one of the viewing stops at t rim. Charlie stands in the darkness, but Wesley stays in car.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You don't know what you're missing, asshole. Charlie walks toward the canyon rim. Suddenly, Betty appe in the headlights standing at the rail - her back to Char with a bouquet of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: ON WESLEY
dialogues.text: Just as he closes his eyes to rest, the CAR PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Campbell?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Is this Neighborly Life Insurance?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: (recovering) Oh, umm, yes, this is Dwight Campbell.

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It's Sue Ann Rogers, Betty Sizemore's friend? I heard from her.

dialogues.speaker: ON CHARLIE
dialogues.text: walking toward the rail. As he nears her, they kiss. Suddenly, REPEATED BLASTS from the car horn. The image of Betty shudders, then blurs, then fades away entirely. Charlie rubs at his eyes tiredly, then slowly trudges back toward the car. Charlie returns and gets into the car. Silence. Wesley stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: you have a good time? You make a little wish?  Silence from Charlie. WESLEY (cont'd) Well, guess what? I found Betty... where she's been, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Where? Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I'm not telling.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I'm not telling 'til you straighten up. You been acting like fucking Jerry Lewis on me and this shit's gotta stop or you can forget about your Betty... I mean it. A slow transformation comes over Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wesley, I'm fine... just tell me where she is.
113 George, Betty, Lyla and the two friends are waiting outsi the hotel for their cars.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: I bought a car from Del, too. He sold me a lemon.

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: Really? I put a hundred and thirty thousand miles on mine.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Huh. I had no idea our little lot was so popular...

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: I never bought a car from Del. But I loved him. In my own way.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I guess we all did. (to Betty) You know, I didn't marry Leslie because I loved  her. I married her to forget you... 100.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh, David...I'm sorry I caused you that much pain. A black jeep 4x4 pulls up and ERIC AUGUSTINO, the actor w plays LONNIE, gets out. BETTY (cont'd) Oh my God! What's Lonnie doing here?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're late, Eric.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: I know. Why are you guys leaving?

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: We did our twenty minutes. Before Eric can take another step Betty SLAPS him across face. FLASHBULBS go off as PHOTOGRAPHERS capture the mome

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: You bastard! How can you even show your face around here? Do you think we're not onto you?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Who the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sorry. She thinks you're someone else. George hustles Betty to his car as photographers continue shoot.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I know exactly who you are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lincoln Town Car rumbles into the dusty parking lot a parks.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: This doesn't look like the kind of place Betty would go to.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Maybe she had to use the bathroom. She  115 pees, doesn't she?!... Wesley tears the photo of Betty from the glove box. 101.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Be careful with that! Charlie takes it back and gingerly secures the tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merle is at the bar, drunk, the only customer on a slow night. Ellen drops two coasters in front of Charlie and Wesley as they sit down.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: What can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: We're Federal Marshals, ma'am. Ellen looks dubiously at their unshaven faces and rumpled clothes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We're looking for this young lady. He slides the photo of Betty across the bar. Ellen's gaze drops to the picture for a second, and Charlie sees what was looking for - a flicker of recognition. He allows himself a satisfied grin. Wesley shows Ellen his badge as Merle checks out the phot

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I haven't seen her.

dialogues.speaker: MERLE
dialogues.text: Sure you have! That's

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Shut up, Merle. Charlie continues to grin at Ellen

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Ma'am, if you've seen this woman--

dialogues.speaker: MERLE
dialogues.text: Betty! That's her name - Betty. Charlie takes the photo and puts it back in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never saw that woman before, and neither has Merle. He drinks too much. And don't try to tell me you're cops. I 102. was married to a cop for nine years, and you're not cops. Now get out of here. Wesley steps behind Merle, takes a handful of his hair an SLAMS his head into the popcorn machine on the bar. Merle staggers away, stunned. Wesley removes the tin popcorn sc from a nearby hook. Ellen reaches for something under the bar, but Charlie's faster. He pins her arm with one hand.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You haven't been very forthcoming with us. They watch Wesley follow Merle at a slow walk around the table, CLOBBERING him over the head about every five step with the popcorn scoop. Merle wobbles with every shot, but won't go down. They be a torturous second lap around the table, punctuated by th CLANG of the scoop against Merle's head.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What's your name, dear?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That's a nice name. After one more CLANGING shot Merle staggers, then falls. Wesley walks over to Charlie and Ellen, drawing his knife

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: That's a really nice name...

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: George and Betty are alone.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Lyla's very nice.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes, she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She told me I was charming and relentless, and would go far in this town. And she said that unlike the other charming, relentless people she knew, she liked me. 103.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She's a good person to know. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where did you study again?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Carleton School of Nursing. Two semesters, but Del made me give it up...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Alright, okay... I think you broke the record for staying in character about three hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: You told me that two hours ago. He pulls up in front of Rosa's apartment and parks. BETTY (cont'd) I haven't been this happy since I was twelve years old.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What happened when you were twelve?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: For Mother's Day, I used all my allowance that I'd been saving to take my mother to Kansas City. We got our nails done and had lunch at "Skies," a restaurant at the top of a building from where you can see the whole city. It was the last outing we took together. She died the following year.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Wow ... You just gave me goosebumps, you know that? You make it all sound so real. Great improv...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I just want everything to be perfect between us.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I know. Listen, we need to take a time out here. Can we talk seriously for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Of course. 104.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: At last! I know how much you want this. You're gifted and extremely determined, but ... it's not up to me.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I know. It's up to us. Betty leans over and kisses George - so deeply that he's surprised to react. She pulls away abruptly and gets out. BETTY (cont'd) I love you, David. And I want to see you tomorrow, and the next day, and the next day. Still surprised, and now a little intrigued, he watches h go inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty comes in and pours a drink from the fridge. Rosa appears in a nightshirt behind her, framed in the doorway

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Were you with him this whole time?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh, God! You scared me! Yes...

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: You still in love? Betty nods.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Does he know you think he's real?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: He is real.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Uh-huh... So, what'd you talk about?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: 118 Rosa gets Rosa goes Oh, my gosh, everything! My trip out here, what we've both been doing, you know...

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: No, I'm not sure I could begin to imagine... So, where'd you go? 105.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: To a party in the Hollywood Hills.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Was it a huge place? With a view of the whole world?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Yes. I'd never been in a place like that before.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: I have, lots of times. My mother used to clean them. I used to piss in their pools. up and starts for her bedroom. She stops. ROSA (cont'd) This isn't fair, you know. Do you always get what you want?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: No, almost never.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: But, you're in love with someone who doesn't exist. You come here, you meet this guy, who should laugh in your face, and instead you leave with him! (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty, you are one-of-a-kind... into her bedroom and closes the door. Betty smiles and nods, sipping at her drink as she retires to her room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his cell Roy Ostrey hears a door open, then the soun approaching footsteps. It's Ballard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elden, let me out of here. Now! This is ridiculous, I need medical attention!

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: That's a nice name for what you need... 106.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Come on, I have to get this dressing off...it itches! And what about my fish? Who is taking care of them? Ballard doesn't say anything. He's very grim, subdued. Ro has never seen him like this.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Just shut up a second and listen... That, uh... that bar in Arizona? Where you said Betty was?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Any idea where it is?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Little place called "Williams," why?

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: I just got something off the wire. The woman who owns it was murdered last night. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I'm not saying I agree with you or nothing, but... what else do you know?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I know plenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palatial, spartan. Lyla is sitting in the inner court of Lloyd Wright home with George at one knee.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She makes me stretch! I got inside my character last night like I haven't done in six years on "Reason". It was a totally rejuvenating experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, George, I was there. I'm not denying that she's good.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She's even taken a job as a nurse! (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Ravell's getting boring, Lyla. 107.

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: We know that...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Can I have an evil twin?

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: No, George, we've already done that with Lonnie. The blind one last year, remember?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, of course. Who can forget the Emmy? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let me bring Betty to the set and see what happens.

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: I don't know, George...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll tell the cast ahead of time. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It'll be like live television! Let's live on the edge a little. You and I can break the mold here!

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: I said I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Fine, but promise me one thing. If we use her, I want to direct those episodes. She's my discovery.

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: Actually, she was my discovery... just like you.

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: "Would you like ground pepper on that salad, Ms. Branch?" Remember?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: yeah. 108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black Lincoln Town car hurdles along the 10 Freeway, revitalized Charlie back at the wheel. Surrounded by traffic, the lights of the city in the distance, the two push on toward their new destination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black Lincoln Town Car - now washed and gleaming - is parked in front of a modest motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie looks like a new man - showered, clear-eyed and energized - he's at the sink shaving as Wesley watches fr his seat on the edge of the bathtub.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So you believed the bartender. Why?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Well... I think I saw her soul.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That's good. You're learning. But let me tell you why I know she was lying. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First off, Betty would never fall for a soap star. It's beneath her.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I dunno, that lady sounded pretty sure...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, no, Betty came here strictly for business, ‘cause it's the biggest market for what she's selling. I should have known it all along. I'm kicking myself  as I shave here. So, first thing we...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, wait a minute... that doesn't make sense.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What doesn't?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: You gimme this bullshit Psychic Friends theory, you believe that dumbshit trucker, you believe this woman... 109.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I never said that I believed...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: No, you believed her, we drove all the way to L.A. so that means you trusted her that much... so why's the rest of her story suddenly so kooky? Huh?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ‘Cause I just don't buy it. Call it instinct. Call it 35 years of professional know-how...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I call it 'nutty' as my shit after I eat Almond Roca...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You need to remember who you're talking to...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I need to get my goddamn head examined. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't rule something out on a whim. Or because she's cute. I've been following your whims all across the U.S. of A. and now I'm tired! Me!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wesley...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: "It's beneath her..." She's a mother

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fucking housewife. her! nothing's beneath Wesley stands up for emphasis, pointing a finger in Charl personal space. Charlie reacts at this, throwing his razo  123 into the sink and turning on Wesley.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
