dialogues.text: Boy, you need to get outta my face... now! You got a feeling, then you do what you gotta do, but don't you ever try to tell me my job. Not ever. It's a standoff. Wesley blinks first. He stalks off and o of sight. In a moment, he returns.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Fine. Just fine... I'll go check some shit on my own then. And don't call me "boy...! 110. He turns and slams into the door frame. He glares at Charlie, then exits. When the front door BANGS SHUT allow himself to go back to his shaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Map in hand, Wesley stand near A GUARD and discreetly ask questions.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: what kinda car's Jasmine drive?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Ahh, Mercedes, I think. Black.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah? The sport utility?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Damn, that's sweet... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She really that good-looking in person?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Better.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Oh fuck... Wesley looks around covertly, then produces a fifty. WESLEY (cont'd) Hey, can you sneak me on the lot?  124 125

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Sure. Wesley smiles and wanders off, headed toward a series of studio buildings in the distance. The guard watches him g GUARD (cont'd) ... it's Sunday, I can sneak anybody on the lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie toys with matches from the Canyon Ranch Bar. Work off a list of names and phone numbers from his Zaurus, he makes calls from his room. 111.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Betty Sizemore, she's got ten kilos... Blonde hair, a great figure... sort of a whole Doris Day thing going on. That's what I said-- Doris Day. You could see her working at the U.N., or something. "The U.N.' “United Nations." Forget it... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody like that? You're sure? Yeah, Detroit by way of Kansas... Alright, let me know if you hear anything, okay? He hangs up. Deletes another one off the list and looks o the window. Checks the now well-worn photo of Betty. He's starting to doubt himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosa stands in the doorway as Betty, wearing one of Rosa' hotter outfits, puts on her makeup.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Are you sure I can borrow this?

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: No, please. Go ahead, it's your funeral...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Rosa...

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: 126 Well, what if this guy's just playing with you? What if he's lying about who he is?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: You should have a little faith in people.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Does he ever talk about medicine? His patients, the hospital?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: All the time. It's always "Loma Vista" this, "Loma Vista" that. The DOORBELL RINGS. Rosa goes to the front door and looks through the peephole, then opens the door. George McCord, flowers in hand, gives his best leading man smile. 112.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You must be Rosa. I've heard so much about you... I'm George McCord.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Not as much as I've heard about you. She's a very nice girl and you better not hurt her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What? Betty appears.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Rosa, so you've met David?

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Sure did! And a funny thing, Betty, he introduced himself to me as George!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh, he does that. (hugging him) It's this silly game he plays. Half the people who know him call him George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't think your friend likes me.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: She's a little jealous, I think. And confused when it comes to men... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, first I thought Patina, and then the Ivy, but then I thought of somewhere a little more romantic. Like my place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Modern glass and steel structure in the hills. Austere. Betty and George sit on the sofa with the lights low and MUSIC playing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: God, I haven't felt like this since I was with Stella Adler in New York. You're so...real. 113. He leans forward slowly to kiss her, but Betty pulls back

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: You never mentioned a 'Stella' to me.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: No, I would have remembered that name. The only Stella I ever knew was a parrot. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was this before Leslie? Before us?... George takes her face in his hands and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I've never met anyone like you, Betty.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I know, that's why we were meant to be together...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, I mean your dedication scares me...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: It's easy to be dedicated, when you care about something...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: 128 Yeah, I felt that way, too, when I first started, but now... the hours, the repetition... it's not all glamour and mall openings anymore. Maybe I should've listened to my people and tried to make the crossover to nights earlier, I don't know... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I just hope it's not too late for me. God! Listen to me, "Me, me, me." It's so easy to get caught up in the whole ego cycle of this business and make it all about yourself. Stop, right? That's it, no more about me tonight, I promise... Let's talk about you...what do you think about me? I'm kidding... Seriously, Betty, I'm doing all the talking here...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: ...but I love listening to you, so that's okay...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thanks. But I'd like to hear what you're feeling...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Well, I just feel that life'll be much sweeter for you now with me around. I promise...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You know, I almost believe that... you're like a warm breeze that's suddenly blown into my life... (laughs) I said that to Leslie, once, at her funeral, remember?...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I remember. You said it to her, but it was meant for me, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes... maybe it was. She kisses him deeply, then allows herself to fall back o the sofa, pulling George down on top of her and kissing h passionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wesley hands Charlie a newspaper folded open to the Entertainment section, where there is a picture of Betty slapping the actor Eric Augustino. George is in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: ..so I'm standing there, minding my own business on Hollywood Blvd., checking out Gladys Knight's star-thing there, I look up at this little souvenir shop dude, Chinese dude, reading a paper... and who do I see? (holding up paper) That's Lonnie. He's the show's Main Prick. And that is definitely Betty. Now, that ain't no coincidence... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found out where they shoot it, and where the dressing rooms are. Charlie studies the photo, troubled by something.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Who's this? 115.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: A doctor on the show... why? Charlie thinks about it, then reaches into his pocket and takes out the photo of Betty with the cardboard David. As compares the photos, Wesley peeks over his shoulder. WESLEY (cont'd) What in the... (simmering) What the hell is this? You've been holding out on me. All this fucking time!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It just didn't fit her profile...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Fuck the profile! That's the same guy!!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: She can't be here because of a... a soap opera. Not a soap opera. That'd make her...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: crazy! No shit, Shaft!! And you ain't far behind...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: 129 130 but she's, no, Betty's smarter than that. She wouldn't be here for a...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: I do not know how the fuck you lasted an hour in this job! Dragging our asses around with the answer to our prayers in your motherfucking jacket... a picture of that cunt right next to the. Charlie cuts Wesley short by grabbing his shirt and pulli him close.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Don't Don't you talk about Betty like that. I don't care who she ends up being, you never use that word again. Got it?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Man, you have got to get some therapy.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I said ‘got it?! 116.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: yeah, I got it. (struggling) Come on, you're stretching out my vest...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You made your point... (drops him) I was wrong. He carefully folds the paper, pockets the photo and straightens his clothing. He straps on his holster and checks his weapon for emphasis. CHARLIE (cont'd) Now, get yourself ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wesley gathering his gear through the open door. Charlie stands looking at himself in the mirror. Touches at the g in his hair. As an afterthought, he tosses on a splash of cologne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George leads Betty past several standing sets and into th ‘operating room' as CREW MEMBERS buzz around. Betty walks with her eyes closed and holding George's hand.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Just a little further... come on... George stops and puts both hands over Betty's eyes. He lo about expectantly and then uncovers them with a flourish. GEORGE (cont'd) Surprise! Betty stares, slowly trying to take in her new surroundin It looks like Loma Vista, but something is different. Odd Cameras, lights, etc. - all the apparatus of a TV show - in plain sight... And very disorienting.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh my gosh...I didn't know I was going to meet your friends today...I dressed a little casual. 117. He leads her to a taped mark on the floor as CAST MEMBERS appear, including JASMINE and BLAKE DANIELS.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's cute...listen, you got the part, and I'm directing. You've only got four lines today, so I thought I'd just spring it on you. No blocking or anything, just stand near the nurse's station... we're gonna do a quick walk-through. Alright? He kisses her cheek and walks off toward the waiting Lyla before she can respond.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Quiet on the set!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Traffic was terrible...

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: No, that's fine, we've only got seventy pages to shoot...take your time. A STAGE MANAGER hands Betty a set of sides and an on-set COSTUMER tries to fit her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: We'll get you into hair and make-up after this, just put this on... The other actors take their positions. Lyla watches from behind the cameras as David readies himself. Chloe enters set with Kleenex tucked into the neck of her costume.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: (to Betty) Hi. I hear you're great. Good luck...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? David...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Your lines'll are in the script, but you can ad lib.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Ad lib? 118.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: In fact, I want you to ad lib, that's the magic I'm after. I wanna give a whole new feel to the show. She's sliding toward a complete meltdown.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Slate it! George steps back behind the cameras. Betty's still froze to her spot, overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Just do what you've been doing. Watch the scene and on your cue take off from there.

Chloe and Blake run through their lines lifelessly, then when they get to Betty's cue. Their faces loom around her menacingly. Staring. The lights are impossibly bright. People begin to shuffle and stare at one another. Lyla cl her throat as George bounds on stage, still smiling.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Betty?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: (to Chloe) I think you stepped on my first line...

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I was talking to her. (to Betty) Do you need anything...? She's freezing up. George approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Betty, I thought this would be the best way. You know, throw you into it...

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: What the hell's going on?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: If you need a minute, that's okay. But I thought you'd want to-- 119.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: David, I don't... Can we talk privately for a second?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Stop calling me David. We're on set, for Christ's sake, you don't have to call me David here. As he pulls away Betty grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this to me?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why am I doing this to you? Isn't this what you wanted? Lyla approaches.

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: Is there a problem, George?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No! No problem, there is no... (to Betty, sotto) What is the problem? Just do that...  thing... you do! Come on! You drove me nuts with this for three days, now do it! George steps back behind the cameras as if nothing's wron Betty still hasn't moved. She's shaking with fear. and crew members find it hard to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: All right, everybody! That's ten minutes!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No! Let me try this!

dialogues.speaker: JASMINE
dialogues.text: (storming off) This is bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: Forget it, George. It was a gamble, didn't work. Nice try.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Let me try this, goddamnit! SHE'S BEEN

dialogues.speaker: I SAID FORGET IT
dialogues.text: George throws down his script and rushes up to Betty, reaches out to him. He brushes her hands away.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know what you had in mind, but I hope you're happy. I put myself on the line for you, my reputation, and you're making me look like an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: What do you mean? What did I do to you...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Who put you up to this? Did my ex-wife ask you to...?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: David, please--

dialogues.speaker: THOUGHT YOU WERE
dialogues.text: The cast 120. who  Betty begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: STAGEHAND
dialogues.text: Leave her alone, George!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: SHUT THE FUCK UP!! You're a fucking grip, go grip something!!! (to Betty) And you're not an actress, you're nothing but a soap opera groupie, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: YOU HAVE NOTHING BETTER TO DO
dialogues.text: Well, why don't you get a fucking life, and stop ruining mine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty stands dead still as George continues to berate her ALL SOUND slowly starts to drop out, then comes back abru with a RUSH. Suddenly a light snaps on for her and she stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry...0h my gosh, are you George McCord?!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ...What? What did you call me? 121.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: George...McCord. You're my favorite actor on...

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: She called you 'George,' George.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: ...did I win some contest?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But I'm David... I mean, I'm not David, but she thinks I am! You heard her... (looking around the group) Stop staring at me... I'm not crazy, she is!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Why are you screaming at me? I mean, what am I... why am I here? I don't...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're doing this now? After all the.. are you sick? Are you going to kill me now?  132 133

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: No, I... I'll leave. Forgive me if I caused you all any trouble... I just, I don't know how I... (to George) I'm sorry. George watches Betty walk off the set. The cast and crew to pretend this scene didn't happen, except for Lyla, who burns a hole into George's back. Their eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George McCord, wearing sunglasses and still angry, stride into the lobby. Charlie and Wesley stand quickly and take out their badges as he approaches.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, gentlemen? 122.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: How do you do, Mr. McCord. We're trying to locate a deranged fan of yours,... a Ms. Betty...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Deranged. That would be the right word. Wesley takes out the photo of Betty. GEORGE (cont'd) That won't be necessary. She's staying with a Rosa something... Hernandez, Herrera. I know it's an 'H' sound... in Silverlake.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thanks so much. You must get bothered by this kind of thing a lot.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: More than you know. Is there anything else?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, that should be more than--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Good. George turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Actually, there is one more thing. George stops. Wesley is suddenly shy, hesitant. WESLEY (cont'd) It's just... well... I watch the show too, and you being Dr. Ravell and all, I thought you could maybe get Jasmine to come out here.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You thought wrong. George pulls away. Wesley grabs his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: It's just for an autograph. It's not for me...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It never is. 123. George wrenches free of Wesley's grip and takes off. Wesley is furious. He catches George in two strides, spin him around and SLAPS him across the face. George's glasse go skittering across the floor. PEOPLE stare.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: You need to learn some manners, friend... reach out to your goddamn fan base a little more. Charlie pulls Wesley away. George is frozen to the spot, humiliated, a pink handprint emerging on his cheek. WESLEY (cont'd) and I saw your movie-of-the-week. It sucked dick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty walks aimlessly along a busy street. She moves with direction, in a daze until a glint of bright light hits h  causing her to turn. She is staring at a black Lincoln sitting in a car lot, sunlight dancing off its chrome. Sh shudders involuntarily at it. Suddenly, she hears a famil voice.

dialogues.speaker: DEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing here? It's Del. He's in a pastel version of his usual shirt, slacks, and tie. DEL (cont'd) Well, are you gonna answer me? What'd you come here for?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I came for love...

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You're not on that soap opera thing again, are you? 'Cause you know what that is?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: It's people with no lives watching other people's fake lives.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: That's right. So, if you know it, why are you in trouble? 124.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: DEL
dialogues.text: You sure don't. Who do you think you are coming to Hollywood, anyway? You should remember where you came from. And who you really are. Del looks up at the sun for a moment, shading his eye fro it. DEL (cont'd) I gotta run. Got some serious clients to meet, with real potential. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn, it's hot! He wipes the sweat from his brow. Betty looks at his handkerchief and sees that it's soaked in blood. Then bac at his face, now obscured by blood pouring down from his head. She stares, horrified, and in that moment Del becomes...  135 MAN, staring back at her as he wipes the sweat from his b

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Who are you talking to? Are you crazy? Betty backs away and melts into the flow of PEDESTRIANS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosa comes home from work and tosses her purse and jacket the chair. No Betty in her room.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Bet-ty!? Did the pizza guy show up yet? She emerges from Rosa's bedroom with toiletries and moves an open suitcase in her room. She barely acknowledges Ros ROSA (cont'd) Are you all right? (no answer) What happened? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dumped you, didn't he? I KNEW IT WHEN I MET HIM!! He's a loser, like the rest of them. Mother-fucker! Rosa now notices Betty packing. 125. ROSA (cont'd) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I'm going back to... I need to... I don't know. Rosa tries to stop Betty for a moment to talk. Betty grab pile of Rosa's clothes and heads for her room. BETTY (cont'd) this is your sweater, right?

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I have to leave now. She tries to put Betty's suitcase away.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: What? No, I'm not gonna let you just run  out of here... You need to talk about what's going on...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: You think I'm crazy, Rosa, but you don't know the half of it. My husband was, ahh...

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Your husband?!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Yes, I had a husband and he was killed two weeks ago in my kitchen. I was right there... Rosa stops.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Jesus!... What are you saying? They stare at each other for a beat. ROSA (cont'd) What?! That you had something to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm just starting to remember it now. I don't... 126.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Yeah, but your running away isn't going to help you with all this...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: There was blood everywhere, Rosa. I saw it, I think I watched the whole thing happen... Oh my God...

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, look, ummm... Let's just talk a little first and you'll feel better, I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorbell rings. ROSA (cont'd) That's our pizza... You can't go yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 137 Charlie watches Betty undress from a nearby fire escape. stares at the object of his desperate search with relief some fascination. Betty's movements are unhurried, mindless. Charlie stares mesmerized, until she steps into the shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wesley gently nudges open the trunk to Betty's LeSabre. T cardboard cut-out of David Ravell pops out at him.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Whoa! What the fuck're you doing here? He breaks it over his knee and throws it in the gutter, t quickly removes the wing nut holding the spare tire. He removes the tire, then raises the panel on the floor of t trunk as Charlie joins him. WESLEY (cont'd) It's all here. It hasn't been touched. The bottom of the trunk is lined with brown paper-wrapped bricks of cocaine. Charlie stares at it, shaking his head WESLEY (cont'd) You were right. Del wasn't lying.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, you were right about what that bartender said. 127. Wesley looks at him. He appreciates the compliment.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: But you were right first. You gotta follow your instincts. Charlie takes a long look at Wesley and smiles proudly.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What do your instincts tell you to do now, kid?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Leave. Take this shit back to Detroit and get the rest of our money.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We could do that. I could be on my way to Florida, and you could go to Thailand  138 and fuck your brains out.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: ...but that's not what we're gonna do, is it?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No... if we don't finish this job, how are we gonna look at ourselves in the mirror? This is it for me, Wesley, she's the last one. My instinct says I gotta see this through with her, and if there's one thing I've tried to teach you here--

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: It's to follow my instincts. And my instincts say get the fuck out of Dodge.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, I said to follow 'my' instincts. Now, we go up there and conclude our business. Case closed. Charlie walks off. Wesley closes the trunk up and prepare to follow him.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: oh, that's fucking democratic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the sound of the BUZZER Rosa goes to the door. She loo through the peephole and sees Charlie holding up a badge. 128.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'm Detective Jefferson--

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Oh... Did Betty call you? Charlie nods. Rosa opens the door, and he enters with Wesley.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: She's got problems, but she's no killer. I hope you guys can straighten this out... Charlie and Wesley exchange a puzzled look.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We'll do what we can. Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet-ty! (to the men) Please, go easy on her. She's had a really rough day. Betty appears. She recognizes the men instantly and freez Charlie's eyes wander over her... slowly. Wesley notices. ROSA (cont'd) These guys are here to help you, Betty.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I don't think so. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosa, I didn't kill Del... they did. Wesley produces a pistol, sitting Rosa forcibly on the so and tapes her mouth and hands. Charlie walks over to Bett

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: We meet again. He moves closer to her... almost whispers. Wesley steps i and quickly tapes her hands. Charlie stops him. CHARLIE (cont'd) Not her mouth... (to Betty) I've spent many long hours in a car with your face staring back at me. I've seen it painted on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) What's wrong with you? 129. A KNOCK at the door ruins Charlie's moment.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: That's our pizza. Wesley hustles Rosa out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Get rid of them. You understand? Betty nods, scared, and looks through the peephole. She stares with disbelief at ROY OSTREY. He KNOCKS again. She opens the door a crack.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Betty! Boy, am I glad to see you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy! What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You're in serious danger!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Ahh, look, right now's not very...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I woulda' been here sooner, but Ballard put me in jail. He still thinks you had Del scalped.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: I never said that! Open the door, Betty. BALLARD shoves Roy aside; Charlie's getting edgy

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Sheriff, I don't...

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: C'mon, Betty, open up! I got some questions for you about...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Have you checked the trunk of that car you're driving, Betty? I think there might be...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: It's not really a good time, guys...

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Don't give me that. I've come two thousand miles for this! 130. Charlie has been listening quietly on the other side of t door and finally snaps.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Two thousand miles? That's nothing! He flings the door open, sticks a pistol in Ballard's fac and yanks them both inside. CHARLIE (cont'd) Hah! You probably flew! I've crossed the river Styx looking for her, pal! I travelled the fucking country to be here! Charlie slams the door and frisks them, taking a gun and  handcuffs from Ballard. Wesley returns with Rosa. CHARLIE (cont'd) (to Betty) Who are these idiots?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: This is Roy Ostrey, he's a reporter. And this is Sheriff Ballard. We all went to Fair Oaks High together...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, this is wonderful... Wesley takes over. He sits Rosa down on the sofa, then pushes Betty down next to her and beckons to Roy.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Come here. He breaks Roy's nose with his pistol. Roy crumples to the floor, holding his face. Betty starts to scream, but Char puts his hand over her mouth. Wesley tapes Roy's hands together, then beckons to Ballar WESLEY (cont'd) Your turn. Ballard drops to his knees in a prayer-like position near aquarium.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: I got two kids and a dog... Wesley grabs his shirtfront and slams him to the floor, t with a foot on his neck, he loops Ballard's arms around o leg of the steel aquarium stand and handcuffs him. 131. Charlie does nothing but stare at Betty, his eyes locked hers. Wesley sees it.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Act professional, remember? Charlie pulls her to her feet. WESLEY (cont'd) What are you doing? Charlie leads Betty out of the room. WESLEY (cont'd) No way! This is not professional!  139

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Then Charlie takes out a knife and cuts the tape from Betty's wrists, touching her hair. Gently. He leaves her standing in the corner while he sits on the edge of t bed. She does.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I s'pose you did that so I could take my sweater off or something.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, just stand there... lemme look at you a minute. Charlie stares intently at her. CHARLIE (cont'd) Do you know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I... I know what you are.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Do you know why I'm here?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I've got a pretty good idea. You're here to kill me, so kill me. You want me to be afraid, but I'm not. I don't care who you are, or why you two killed my husband... Charlie studies her, then sets his gun down on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You really... didn't have anything to do with what Del was doing, did you? 132.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I have no idea what he was mixed up in... it was always something.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So you weren't involved with him in his pathetic attempt to diversify? (off her blank look) Were you mixed up in the drugs, Betty?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Drugs? God, no! I'm totally against  drugs.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Damn, life is strange. I had you figured for this cold-blooded, calculating bitch-- Not that I didn't admire you for it. Charlie slowly folds his knife and pockets it.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: well, if you're not going to slit my throat, why'd you come up here?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wesley stands over Ballard, about to tape his mouth. Rosa Roy are sitting in chairs opposite them, their mouths and wrists already taped.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: You killed that bartender in Arizona and the trucker in Texas, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: How did you find Betty?

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: I just put it all together. I knew David, Lonnie and Chloe were from that show. Roy starts freaking out, trying to talk through the tape. BALLARD (cont'd) Betty thinks they're real people. It sounded crazy, but it was worth a shot. Roy is apoplectic... 133.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: What do you want?! Wesley tears his tape off.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: That's a lie! I figured it out! I've been trying to tell this dumbass--

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Roy Ostrey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --small-time, pissant, Barney Fife--

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: SHUT UP! Shut the fuck up, both of you, before I kill you!

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'm the one who watched the show...I was...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Did Chloe crack?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Totally. She came apart like a house of cards. They dropped the charges...

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: Goddamn... how 'bout Jasmine?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: She's a lesbian. Wesley immediately pulls his gun and points it at Roy's h

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: You lie, motherfucker...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I swear to God! Rosa STAMPS her feet, drawing Wesley's attention. She tri to talk through the duct tape; gestures for him to come t her.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: What?! You scream, you die. He yanks the tape off. Rosa winces.

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: I have a tape of today's show. 134.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is sitting on the bed. Charlie leans against the wa facing her. He has trouble starting this.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I never meet people like you. I'ma  garbageman of the human conditon. I deal with trash, mostly, people willing to trade any part of themselves for a few more minutes of their rotten lives. But you... you're different.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I am?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sure. You could probably have any thing you wanted... somebody as beautiful and stylish as yourself, and you don't even realize it. Betty looks curiously over at Charlie. CHARLIE (cont'd) I'm appreciably older than you, but my health is good. I take care of myself, and I got some money socked away. You'd never have to work agin, that's for sure. I'd treat you like a queen.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Umm, I don't think that...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wait. Let me get this out. (clears his throat) I like the symphony, walks in the rain, sunsets, animals and children. I read passionately, and I like to discuss things. I'm basically conservative, but flexible. I've been involved in the death of thirty-two people, but I can live with that because the world is lighter by thirty-two pieces of shit, excuse my language.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: "Thirty-two?"

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, thirty-three, but I'm not counting Del, on account of you... so, what do you think? 135. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You probably feel I'm flattering myself to see us together.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I don't feel that, no. I just....I'm not really who you think I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one is, honey. Here, listen to this... "I£ who I am and who I hope to be should meet one day, I know they will be friends." Now that's beautiful. Betty is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I wrote that when I was twelve... where'd you get that?!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (he pulls out the diary) I know. I borrowed it from your grandparents because I... I... it doesn't matter. Don't worry, they're fine... (he gives the diary back) Look, I used to feel that same way, said practically those same words, sitting at night in a foxhole in Korea... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've chased you across the country, Betty, and I come to find out we're a lot more alike than you'd think.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I thought you were a garbageman of humanity, or something.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes, but I'd sort of like to put that behind me now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wesley is engrossed in watching "A Reason to Love." Behin him, Ballard quietly walks his feet up the wall until he' completely upside down. He rubs one foot against the othe until one pantleg is above his cowboy boot. Rosa and Roy watch. He finally lifts the boot off. It falls soundlessly onto chest. A small pistol is revealed, holstered above his an He works the holster open using the edge of the fishtank. 136. Roy and Rosa COUGH LOUDLY at the same time to cover the noise. Wesley glares at them. Ballard gets the pistol free. But it falls into the fisht The air goes out of Roy's sails. Ballard has fucked up ag On screen, Chloe and Jasmine kiss and embrace. Wesley rea  as if he was slapped.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY
dialogues.text: goddamn! Wesley immediately runs the sequence back to view it agai Ballard KICKS the wall of the fishtank with his cowboy bo Roy and Rosa cover the sound again with COUGHING. Wesley pauses the T.V. and looks around. WESLEY (cont'd) What's your problem? Ballard KICKS at the tank again. But he can't break the glass. Roy can't take it any more. He launches himself at tank, grabs it by the rim and pulls it down on top of himself. A torrent of water, fish, plants and gravel pour down upon him. WESLEY (cont'd) You stupid piece of fuck! He leaps at Roy and starts kicking him savagely. Rosa thr herself onto Wesley's back, knocking him to the floor. Ballard paws through the muck, scattering fish and gravel everywhere. He spots a glint of metal in the sand. Wesley struggles out from under Rosa. Just as he gets fre Ballard FIRES, hitting him TWICE into his chest. Wesley stares in disbelief at the blood rushing out of him. Then Ballard, as if trying to link the two. He slumps to the floor and opens his mouth to scream WESLEY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: D-A-A-A-D-D-D-Y-Y-
dialogues.text: Charlie opens the bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wesley                         Charlie sees Wesley turn to him as Ballard FIRES again. Wesley's face explodes. The flying lead drives Charlie ba to the bedroom. Crawling through the muck, Roy notices a fish flopping helplessly on the carpet inches from his face. 137.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Those're Japanese koi!

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: 143-144 Yes! How'd you know that?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You gotta get 'em in water right away!

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: We're in a shootout, Roy! Shut up about the damn fish!

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: YOU shut up! (to Rosa) They're beautiful, but get them some water. He gently hands her the fish, then picks up Wesley's near gun. Rosa nods; she's amazed that he knew what it was. Sh looks at Roy in a slightly different way before crawling toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie FIRES back from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ, they shot my boy! Enraged, he empties his pistol at the living room. Ballar and Roy return fire, and Charlie ducks back in. CHARLIE (cont'd) (reloading) How the hell did this happen? I'm in a goddamn shoot-out! Wesley? What the fuck happened out there?! He opens the door, and a bullet slams into the doorjamb n his head. He ducks back in. Charlie sags against the wall, looking toward Betty. CHARLIE (cont'd) That's my son! My son is dead!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. 138.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You're sorry? YOU'RE THE REASON WE'RE

dialogues.speaker: UNTIL YOU CAME ALONG
dialogues.text: Charlie fights back his grief. BETTY (cont'd) What do you want from me? Charlie can't handle the moment. He breaks for the door, and BLASTS away. This time he's nicked in the shoulder. H stumbles back, losing his balance. His gun falls and slid right into Betty's hand. Equally surprised they stare at another. Charlie slumps over in his defeat as Betty holds a shaky pistol on him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosa crawls to a flower vase and dumps a second koi into water inside. Roy and Ballard crouch behind the open archway, using the hanging beads as protection.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: (checks his gun) We need ammo... Go check his jacket, I'll cover you.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I'm not going out there! Let's wait for the real police...

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: You gotta go, we're pinned down!

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: So why can't we just sneak outside? Huh?

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Lady, you don't just run away from crime... besides, Betty's in there. 139.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 147 (checking) You wanna see if he has more shells, go ahead. I say we wait...

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: No, no, no... you don't know shit about procedure! You don't send your best...

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I've got the working gun, Elden, me! You wasted all your bullets so you crawl out there. Ballard stares at him in disbelief, then back at the clos bedroom door. Ballard starts off on his belly.

dialogues.speaker: BALLARD
dialogues.text: Goddammit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LONG BEAT passes. POLICE SIRENS wail in the distance. Betty moves close to Charlie to look at his shoulder. He watches her intently.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: If we went out that window right now we'd have a chance...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I better go check on them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wait, Betty... you still haven't answered me.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: This is really awkward... The SIRENS are coming closer. He waves her off.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Ahh, it's too late, anyway. It's too late. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I could shoot my way out, maybe take one of them with me... If you'd gimme my gun back. 140.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather not...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Betty, I don't wanna shrivel up alone in some stinking prison. No way. I've got some professional pride. And I don't want anybody else to get the credit for taking me out.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: ..what're you saying?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: When a Roman general knew a battle was lost, he'd throw himself on his sword. Charlie fumbles in his pocket, then pulls out the photo o Betty with the cardboard David Ravell. Charlie's CHARLIE (cont'd) Did... did you really come here because you love this guy?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Yes... Not the actor, though, the doctor. I think. sinks slowly to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So all this...really was because of that soap opera? My son is dead because you came out here to be with that doctor? A fake doctor?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have put it quite that way, but...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Wesley didn't even want to come up here. He warned me, but I insisted... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to ask you, Betty...are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I don't think I am. Charlie remains sitting pensively for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I want you to listen to me, Betty. People don't lie when they're about to die.  141. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need that doctor. You don't need that actor. You don't need any man. It's not the forties, honey. You don't need anybody. You've got yourself... and that's more than most people can say. Charlie reaches out slowly and takes the gun from Betty. doesn't fight him. He kisses her hand and steps into the bathroom and closes the door. A single GUNBLAST sends a shiver through Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV Newscast CLOSE SHOT of an ANCHORMAN.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORMAN
dialogues.text: In a story that police say is bizarre, even for Hollywood, a father-son team of killers tracked a Kansas soap opera fan halfway across the country, only to find themselves the victims in a final, bloody confrontation... The Anchorman continues as the CAMERA PULLS BACK to revea Lyla and George watching television in a plush living roo

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: This story is beyond belief, which is perfect for us. It's free advertising and it's gonna run for months.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't think she can do it. You saw what happened.

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: You fucked it up. Who wouldn't freeze in those circumstances? And I don't care what her problems are. She wouldn't be the first one in that cast with problems. We have nothing to lose by making her an offer.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What about me? Don't you wanna know how I feel about it? I'm the one who...

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: Why would I give a shit how you feel. And I got news for you. I loved your ‘icy  water’ idea the other day... I'm toying 142. with the idea of killing David Ravell off in a boating accident.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's not a bad idea. How many episodes before he comes back? Lyla shakes her head "no." GEORGE (cont'd) Jesus, don't do that! If it gets around that you fired me, I'll never land a pilot.

dialogues.speaker: LYLA
dialogues.text: Then do as you're told. Get her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Betty sit across from one another in a booth. Betty listens patiently. Her former co-workers try to rem busy but can't help gawking.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for what I did. It was inexcusable. I'm sorry for the things I said, and for not respecting you, and for all the stupid things that... Darlene approaches, puts a piece of paper on the table.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: When you have a minute...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look, I don't really like the whole idea of autographs, and I'm kind of in the middle of...

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Don't flatter yourself. It's the check. She walks off.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh. Of course... sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (grabbing it up) My treat. You were saying... something about how stupid you've been?  143.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Right... I was. I was an idiot, plain and simple, and I hope you can find it in your heart to forgive me. How's that?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Kinda like you'd been saying it since you got on the plane...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I have... did it sound that bad?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Mmm-hmm. Listen, I forgive you, Mr. McCord...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: George...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: George. I do. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My best friend once said if you were any handsomer it would be a crime...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thanks...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: ... it's too bad you're such an asshole. 's the only thing that Del was ever right about. George winces... accepts it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, that's... okay. Fair enough. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, now that we've sort of settled the ‘asshole' thing, is there any chance you'll come back to the show? At all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. David Ravell sits with Nurse Betty in a diner, catchi bite to eat before going back on shift. They smile at one another over their meals.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: there's always a chance, David.  151 152 153

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Right. But will there be a tomorrow, and the next day, and the next? 144.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (whispering to him) Doctor, if you were any handsomer it'd be a crime...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I guess that means you're free tonight. Of course, it's up to you...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: No, it's up to us. I love you, David. And I want to see you tomorrow, and the next day, and the next day... (they kiss)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darlene, the other waitresses, the cooks and assorted customers gather at the counter to watch Betty on televis Sheriff Ballard beams from a nearby stool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids are out of control, but Sue Ann's oblivious. She leaps from her chair.

dialogues.speaker: SUE ANN
dialogues.text: That's my best friend!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, Rosa, Danny and Sra. Herrera watch Betty lean across table, take David's face in her hands and move into a romantic kiss. On the sofa, Rosa takes Roy's hand in hers.

dialogues.speaker: POSTSCRIPT
dialogues.text: Rosa Herrera received 11 phone calls off the business cards Betty handed out. But she fell in love with Roy Ostrey, married him and moved to Kansas.  154 pay vacation in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty watches the pilgrims on their way to St. Peter's as sips a cup of coffee. HER WAITER stands nearby with one e on a TV set that broadcasts "A Reason to Love" in Italian 145.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Could I get some service here, please? Without looking, the waiter approaches, tops off her cup moves back to watching the show. Betty smiles knowingly a this, takes a sip and settles back in her seat. Slowly, t world passes by.

dialogues.speaker: POSTSCRIPT
dialogues.text: Betty Sizemore appeared in 63 episodes of "A Reason to Love." She is using her earnings to for a nursing degree and is currently on Europe. The Europe.
